That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Navigation Act 1912, the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 and various other Acts relating to transport, and for related purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Transport Legislation Amendment Bill contains amendments to a number of Acts administered by the Transport and Communications portfolio. The amendments are of a kind which it has been the practice, in recent years, to make in an omnibus Bill of this nature.
Navigation Act 1912
Under the Act there exist numerous administrative discretions for which there is no avenue for review other than a Court of Marine Inquiry (CMI).

CMIs usually deal with marine accidents or casualties but for administrative review they are an expensive, cumbersome and outdated mechanism. This is evidenced by the fact that a CMI has not received an administrative decision in over 60 years.

In addition, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has been concerned about the lack of a simple review mechanism for decisions taken under the Act and its subordinate legislation.

In light of the Government's policy to centralise administrative review functions as far as possible in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a review of all administrative decisions under the Act was conducted in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department. The results of this review are implemented in the Bill. The Bill will insert new Part IXA into the Act which lists, section by section, all the administrative decisions appropriate for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987

The Act is to be amended to ensure that funds it provides are used to best effect. The intention underlying this Act is to provide financial incentives to promote the introduction of modern, advanced technology trading ships which put in place the improvements in shipboard productivity and work practices recommended by the Maritime Industry Development Committee (MIDC). An integral part of these improvements is the introduction of multiskilled crews, smaller than the existing norms within the industry.

It has become apparent that there is the possibility of a diversion of funds under the Act to provide what amounts to windfall gains to operators of small passenger ships intended for the coastal cruising market. Such ships are eligible for grants under the Act as it is presently drafted but their crew training and operational requirements fall outside the scope of the MIDC recommendations. Consequently, the payment of a grant to operators of these ships is not warranted. The Government estimates that if no action is taken to remedy this situation up to $6m could be paid to such operators over the next two years.

The Government has therefore decided to amend the Act and target it more carefully. This will be done by making it clear that the focus of the Act is substantial cargo carrying ships (i.e., ships over 60 metres in length) and by excluding ships intended wholly for the carriage of passengers from the Act.

The original definition of `trading ship' in the Act was intended to include commercial ferry operations, such as those across the Bass Strait. Such ships are in the mainstream of Australian shipping and are capable of achieving the efficiency and productivity improvements generated as part of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act package. Accordingly, the amended Act will still enable a large ferry operation to qualify for a grant, provided it carries a significant amount of cargo in addition to its passengers.

To protect the revenue from claims for ships which are to be excluded by these changes, the amendments are to take effect from the date of introduction of this Bill. Existing applications will remain valid.
Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

This Act gives effect to the International Convention for the Protection of Pollution from Ships 1973-78. Annexes III and V of the Convention relating to pollution by harmful packaged substances and by garbage will come into operation shortly.

The Bill will extend the parts of the Act relating to Annexes III and V to ships normally under State-Northern Territory jurisdiction, until the States-Northern Territory have parallel legislation in place.
The amendments are necessary for Australia to meet its international Convention obligations and have been agreed by the State-Northern Territory marine Ministers.
Other Amendments
The remaining amendments in the Bill are to correct drafting errors and make minor editorial improvements.
Financial Impact Statement

On the basis of the number of potentially eligible passenger ships on order in Australian shipyards for domestic delivery, it is estimated that the amendments of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987 could save the Government up to $6m over the next two years. No figures are available beyond 1990, but it is possible the total savings could be double this amount by 1992, when the Act expires.
There will be no significant costs, revenues or savings to the Government arising from the other amendments in the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Government has always considered the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park to be one of the outstanding legacies of the Whitlam Labor Government, one which the Fraser and Queensland governments wisely built on and an issue, I hope, that will continue to receive bipartisan support.

There have been notable achievements in the 13 years since the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the commencement of work on the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park:

the Great Barrier Reef region and all of the islands within it have been inscribed, with Queensland Government support, on the World Heritage List reflecting the importance Australians attach to this area;
the entire Great Barrier Reef Marine Park has been zoned with the zoning plan for the last section, the Mackay-Capricorn section, taking effect on 1 August 1988;
the establishment of a management approach which allows multiple use, while ensuring that the conservation values of the marine park are not devalued; and

strong co-operative arrangements have been developed with Queensland to ensure a complementary aproach to the management of Queensland lands and waters adjacent to the Marine Park and thus add to the protection of the reef.

The practical experience gained from managing the Marine Park during this period has highlighted the desirability of amending provisions of the Great Barrier Reef marine Park Act to ensure that these positive developments continue.

Honourable senators will be well aware of the increasing level of commercial and non-commercial activity in the Great Barrier Reef. The number of visitors to the reef has been steadily increasing; it is one of Australia's main tourist destinations. There has been an expansion of commercial fisheries further offshore; an increase in recreational fishing; an increase in private boat use; an expansion of the number of tourist facilities, including resorts, pontoons and the world's first floating hotel. Tourism activities include diving, scenic cruises, helicopter and aircraft services and day trips to islands and coral cays. The relatively recent introduction of high speed catamarans, which can move several hundred people each trip, has opened up the more remote parts of the marine park to tourism.

This growth has increased pressure, not only on the environmental quality of the marine park but also on the marine resources, scientific research and general use of the marine park. There is also a growing concern that this pressure, whether by accident or deliberate act or omission, will result in damage to the marine park. Therefore given the scale of commercial activity and the limits to management resources, it is essential that there are incentives for users of the Great Barrier Reef to comply with marine park zoning plans.

Mr President, it has been some time since the penalties applicable for breaches of the Act have been reviewed. With the increased level of activities in the marine park and the substantial profits to be gained, it is obvious that the existing penalties are inadequate to deter breaches of the Act.

To rectify this situation it is necessary to transfer the main offence provisions from the regulations to the body of the Act. This transfer will allow the applicable penalties to be increased. The Bill provides generally for fines up to $10,000 for natural persons and $50,000 for corporations, although higher penalties apply in relation to some specific offences such as the discharge of waste, which incurs a penalty of up to $250,000 for corporations. This compares with penalties of up to $5,000 which apply currently in the regulations.

The Bill provides for the transfer to the principal Act of provisions dealing with offences in zoned and unzoned areas, contravention of conditions of permissions or authorities issued by the Authority in respect of entry into zones, contravention of directions issues by the Authority, the removal of property in the marine park, the discharge of waste in the marine park and the use of vessels and aircraft in the commission of offences. I am sure honourable senators will agree that these offences can be serious as they could cause damage to this unique natural resource. Consequently there should exist appropriate penalties.

It should be noted that the transfer of penalties from the regulations to the Act will require a revision of the regulations. The transfer provisions and the associated increase in penalties therefore will not come into effect until these regulations have been revised and passed by the Parliament.

The policing of the marine park is a complex and time-consuming task. The Great Barrier Reef is an enormous area of over 350,000 square kilometres, which is an area larger than Victoria and Tasmania combined, and the resources necessary to supervise the use of the marine park must therefore be used effectively and efficiently. However, there is some concern, shared by the Government, that marine park inspectors presently have insufficient power to pursue, search and apprehend people suspected of committing offences against the Act. For example an offender, once outside the boundaries of the marine park, is not at present subject to the authority of inspectors.

The Government believes that it is essential to the management of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and its ultimate protection, that inspectors have the necessary powers to enforce the Act. As a consequence the Bill provides for a number of amendments, including extending search and seizure powers to include aircraft and providing for the search of people, vessels and aircraft should offenders be apprehended outside the marine park.

The Government recognises that the extension of police powers to marine park inspectors should be limited. The Bill therefore only extends these powers where a police officer is unavailable and only where there has been an uninterrupted pursuit of the offender from a place within the marine park to a place outside the marine park where the offender has been apprehended.

In addition, there have been circumstances in the past where an offence against the Act has resulted in damage or has posed a threat to the environment of the marine park. The Act, as it now stands, does not provide explicitly for remedial or preventative action to be taken nor can costs for any clean up be billed to the offender who caused the damage. As mentioned, the risk of environmental damage posed by increased use of the marine park has significantly changed since the Act's inception. There is, I believe, a need to deal with this risk effectively. The Bill therefore provides for the Commonwealth Minister responsible for the Act, provided there are reasonable grounds for believing an offence has been committed against the Act, to take such steps as are necessary to remedy actual damage or prevent possible damage to the marine park. Provision is also made for the Minister's powers to be delegated to the Authority or the Chairman of the Authority, subject to the directions of the Minister.

As an adjunct to the clean up or prevention of environmental damage provision, an amendment is proposed to allow the reasonable costs of the clean up to be recovered from the offender once a conviction has been obtained. The Bill also provides for the court, at the time of the conviction, to make orders concerning the payment of the debt, so as not to place the burden of another hearing on the judicial system.

In meeting the objective of conserving the Great Barrier Reef it is essential that the Authority be given the full range of management tools to ensure the effective protection and management of the marine park while providing for reasonable use. One deficiency in the current Act is that obtaining a conviction does not necessarily deter future contraventions by the offender, nor does it undo the environmental damage resulting from the offence. While the Bill provides for remedial action to be taken, there may be circumstances where it would be preferable to prevent the occurrence or recurrence of the offence. The Bill therefore provides for the Supreme Court of a State or Territory to grant an injunction where there has been or is likely to be a contravention of the Act.

I should emphasise, Mr President, that the court may grant the injunction on the application not only of the Authority, but also on the application of a person whose interests have been, or would be affected by the conduct in question. This new provision allows individuals to protect their interests while at the same time enforcing the provisions of the Act. This will facilitate a far more effective enforcement of the Act without incurring additional Commonwealth expense.
The Authority's education expertise and its experience in natural resource management is recognised worldwide and is the subject of many requests for assistance.

Honourable senators will recognise the valuable work the Authority has undertaken to inform and educate Australians, particularly users of the marine park, of its value and the need to use it wisely. Indeed, honourable senators will be interested to hear that the Great Barrier Reef Aquarium, the Authority's major education and interpretive facility, has attracted over 320,000 visitors in its first year of operation and has won an award for the best Queensland tourist facility. The aquarium plays an important role in the Authority's education function and was funded with the assistance of the Commonwealth Government, as a bicentennial project, the Queensland Government, the private sector and the community of Townsville.

I recently had the opportunity of addressing the Sixth Coral Reef Symposium in Townsville which was attended by 650 scientists and managers, the majority of whom were from overseas. The aim of the symposium was to promote global understanding of the growth and maintenance of coral reefs, which are an important natural resource to many countries, particularly small developing island nations in the Pacific and Indian oceans. Often many of these nations do not possess the scientific and managerial infrastructures to work by themselves to understand the complexities of coral reef ecosystems and to plan for the wise management of these important natural features. At this symposium I took much pride in the fact that Australia through the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, mainly as a result of support from the Federal Government, is in the vanguard of coral reef research and management throughout the world and has much to offer these smaller nations.

However, at present the Act does not permit the Authority to provide assistance to international organisations or individuals unless it directly concerns the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Australians should be proud of the reputation of the Authority and would, I am sure, want to share the Authority's expertise with other countries. As a consequence the Bill amends the Act by permitting the Authority to assist other institutions and individuals in environment management issues.

To ensure that the assistance provided does not detract from the Authority's prime responsibility to manage the marine park, requests for assistance will be subject to ministerial approval. Provision is also made for the recovery of the costs of providing such assistance.

Mr President, the Bill also introduces a number of other measures to streamline and enhance the administration of the Act. These relate to the disclosure of pecuniary interests of members of the Authority and the Great Barrier Reef Consultative Committee, application of the Audit Act 1901 to financial, audit and reporting functions of the Authority, the jurisdiction of courts in respect to offences against the Act and the updating of the Act to reflect current drafting policy.

In conclusion the Bill will be a significant step in assisting marine park managers to meet the new challenges that now exist while enhancing the protection of one of the world's greatest natural assets, the Great Barrier Reef, for the benefit of present and future generations of Australians. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for an increase in the salary of the next Governor-General after he is sworn in February 1989. Section 3 of the Constitution fixes the salary of the Governor-General for the term of office, therefore the salary fixed at the commencement of the Governor-General's appointment must be set at a level that will still be appropriate at the end of the term. The Income Tax Assessment Act provides that the official salary of the Governor-General shall be exempt from income tax.

The Governor-General Act 1974 provided for a salary of $30,000. It was amended in 1977 to increase the salary to $37,000 and by the Fraser Government in 1982 to increase the salary quite considerably to $70,000. It is now proposed that the Governor- General's salary be $95,000-a figure that will remain unchanged through the period of the next Governor-General's appointment.

The principle that has governed the calculation of this amount is that used to determine the salaries of Governors-General in the past; that is, to keep the average salary over a notional five year appointment somewhat ahead of the estimated average annual income, after tax, of the Chief Justice of Australia. This approach what not followed strictly when the salary was last calculated, with the result that the average exceeded the after tax income of the Chief Justice by some $15,000 per annum over the first five years of the term.

The current calculation, however, would result in less than half that differential over the next five years, based on no more than 5% annual CPI increases in the Chief Justice's salary. This calculation, it should be noted, ignores the fact that changes will take place in the rates of income tax during the period, and does not take account of the possibility that there will be additional increases in federal judges' salaries arising from Remuneration Tribunal reviews.

I would only add that this Government adheres to the three important principles that should apply to consideration by the Parliament of the Governor-General's salary; as put forward by Prime Minister Whitlam in 1974 and endorsed by the Fraser Government. They were that the Governor-General's salary should be dealt with in a non party way; that the salary should recognise the importance and place of this high office, and that the appointment of a Governor-General should not depend on personal wealth or the availability of other income. The proposed salary is commensurate with the office, it is economically responsible, and it re-establishes the traditional relativity between the Chief Justice and the Governor-General. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988 INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988
Consideration resumed from 31 August.
Clause 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee was considering amendment No. 2 to clause 3 moved by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall remind the Committee of the stage we had reached. The amendment that I moved seeks to insert a new paragraph in clause 3, the objects clause. It is a quite important clause because the Industrial Relations Commission, as it will be if this Bill is passed-the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission if the Bill does not pass-is required to act to advance the objectives set out in the Industrial Relations Bill. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will know, the objectives clause is not a matter of form. It is a clause which, if enacted, will have some importance in providing a guide for the major wage fixing body and its actions.

SPEECH.PARA: What is proposed is that we should insert a further object which is to encourage the growth of productivity and international competitiveness of Australian industry. In response, the Minister's general complaint was that the amendments are not consistent with the general tenor of the proposed Act and and would have some sort of negative impact on the administration of the Act or on the administration of the Federal scheme of industrial relations, with the mixture of State and Federal tribunals. The position, of course, is that the Government, in its own set of objects in the Act as presently drafted, has made reference to the importance of the economic interests of the Australian community. The existing objective (c) reads:

. . . to ensure that, in the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes, proper regard is had to the interests of the parties immediately concerned and to the interests (including the economic interests) of the Australian community as a whole . . .

I pointed out in the committee debate yesterday that the view of the Opposition is similar to that of the Business Council of Australia which suggests that a strong signal needs to be sent to the Commission about this fundamental question of international competitiveness. I suggest to the Minister that it in no way flies in the face of the Government's general request that the economic interests of the Australian community be considered. It simply makes specific the fact that international competitiveness is of fundamental importance. It seems to me to be totally in line with the Minister's own rhetoric in the area of his direct responsibilities, namely, industry, technology and commerce.

I invite the Minister to indicate that the Government is prepared to give some consideration to matters raised in this Parliament and to adopt a reasonably open mind to suggestions which could give rise to real improvement in the legislation. The simple point is that we are suggesting to the Government and the Committee that a specific reference of the kind we are seeking to insert-to the importance of productivity and international competitiveness-would be a very useful additional guideline for the Industrial Relations Commission to have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —One cannot take too much note of all the signals that one gets from the Business Council of Australia. One must have doubts whether a signal from the Business Council of Australia is sufficient to determine a legislative purpose or objective.
—I am not suggesting that is the reason. The Council is putting that view in common with us.

—I understand that. The Government does not support this amendment-the specific provision for this `international competitiveness' phrase in the Bill. I certainly share with Senator Chaney his concern about that issue, in a wider context. Object (c) in clause 3 of the Bill already provides that proper regard should be had to the interests, including economic interests, of the Australian community as a whole. Clause 90 of the Bill requires the Commission to take into account the public interest and have regard to the state of the national economy and the likely effects on the national economy of any proposed award or order, with special reference to likely effects on the level of employment and inflation. The fact that those provisions are in the legislation is not in itself an argument against including a reference to international competitiveness in the subjective clause. But we would argue that those things are sufficiently wide to embrace the concept of international competitiveness of Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The objection to the inclusion of this phrase `international competitiveness' is more substantial than that. In attempting to establish that point, I refer to the views of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. The Committee of Review stated:

. . . the case against imposing an explicit statutory requirement upon the Commission to have regard to `international competitiveness' is reinforced by our doubts about the applicability of such a criterion. Those doubts flow from the existence of a floating exchange rate, uncertainty about the effects of wage levels on currency values and the difficulty of judging whether the currency is overvalued or undervalued. This issue is one which should properly be discussed in the Commission.

It had some other views on that of the same kind too but its position, I think, and the position of the Government are reinforced by what the Commission has actually done and said in national wage cases. For example, in its recent decision the Commission took into account the need to improve Australia's economic performance and it listed eight factors of which it took particular account, including levels of domestic inflation and future prospects, the state of the external economy, productivity movements, and scope of the decision to assist further improvements in productive performance of work. In that decision it devoted a special section to what it described as the economic context, examining the issues of economic activity, employment and unemployment, inflation, nominal real wages, productivity profitability, and the external economy.

The Commission commented that the relevance of external economy, and of the external economy to its decisions affecting wages and other labour costs is not straightforward, referring to the substantial impact on competitiveness of the exchange rates. In dealing with the two tier wage decision of March 1987, it commented on the recognition by all parties of `the importance of maintaining international competitiveness for continued wage restraint for revival and private investment' and so on. In determining increases under the two tier system it said that it would have regard to the broad range of industrial economic and social factors affecting Australian society. So in essence the Government's non-acceptance of this amendment is based on two things. Firstly, there are already references in clause 90 and in the objectives clause of the legislation which require the Commission to consider these matters in a general sense. Secondly, the concept of international competitiveness is very much dependent on a floating exchange rate. Thirdly, the Commission, from time to time, in the course of its work and decisions in national wage cases is already taking those matters into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce for his remarks. I simply wish to say by way of response that it seemed to me, from the passages that the Minister read from the decisions of the Commission, that what we are advocating here is quite compatible with what the Commission sometimes does in its decisions but not invariably does in its decisions. It is not suggested that by putting this objective in one is putting down some sort of guidelines which would bind the Commission to make rulings on the basis of some particular measure of international competitiveness. Rather it is simply making the point that this is something which is of fundamental long term importance to the economy and to the capacity of the economy to pay higher wages which, in the end, is what the work force is concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing I want to say is that to save the time of the committee I do not propose to divide on each of these amendments. I would ask the Australian Democrats spokesman, Senator McLean, to indicate-if he does not wish to speak on the matter-that he is not supporting the amendment and in those cases where I do not believe it is a major issue then I will accept that we have lost on the voices in appropriate cases. I would invite Senator McLean to indicate whether the Australian Democrats support or do not support this particular amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated to Senator Chaney that we will not be supporting his amendment, nor the amendments through to those listed under serial 11 of our schedule of debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean has just rendered what I was about to say redundant. I just want to come back to the international competitiveness point. I certainly would argue that the concept of international competitiveness is dependent on a multiplicity of factors, only one of which essentially is within the province of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. For example, when we discuss the clauses on union structures and things like that, reference is always made to countries such as Japan and Germany, as well as many others. I am talking essentially about manufacturing. References are always made to those economies, about how competitive they are and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is highly competitive with those countries in terms of manufacturing wages. Australia has about half the wages level that exists in Japan in manufacturing and considerably lower wages than in Germany, the United States and various other countries which are used as points of comparison. But the notion of international competitiveness is very dependent, as I said, on exchange rates and on a whole range of other factors which are not within the province of the Commission, such as management skills, design quality and all those things that go to international competitiveness. We could go on talking about this forever but I do not want to do that. I just wanted to say those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Agreement has been reached on the way this Bill should be handled in committee. With the concurrence of the Committee, I propose to handle it in the agreed form, taking the Bill as a whole but calling groups of amendments as they become relevant. For this to work it will be necessary for everyone to be relevant to the amendments before us. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to object (b) of the Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, paragraph 3 (b), line 2, leave out ``by conciliation and arbitration''.
Object (b), as it is drafted, provides as follows:

to provide a framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration in a manner that minimises the disruptive effects of industrial disputes on the community.

Quite clearly, the general objective will command broad, almost universal, community support in the sense that people wish to see the disruptive effects of industrial disputes minimised. The amendment simply takes out the words `by conciliation and arbitration' because, in the view of the Opposition, it is a wider matter than mere conciliation and arbitration. The amendment does not suggest that conciliation and arbitration should not be available and that it is not one of the very important mechanisms which can be used to minimise the disruptive effects of industrial disputes. But we believe it is very important that the whole framework of industrial relations be one which lends itself to a minimisation of industrial disputes between employers and employees. We would see there being other measures. Indeed, the legislation provides for various penalties to be imposed and so on. So there are much broader questions involved than simply conciliation and arbitration in this objective. We suggest that the meaning of the clause would be improved by the removal of those words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not support the removal of the words in question. The Government's view is that the purpose of the objects in this clause of the Bill is to reflect the main focus of the legislation. The whole thrust of the legislation reflects the decision by the Government that Australia is best served by an industrial relations system based primarily on processes of conciliation and arbitration. That characteristic can be found in the State industrial systems. It is desirable in our view that consistency should be retained across the country in the various industrial relations tribunals. The Bill, in clause 89, describes the general functions of the Industrial Relations Commission. One of those functions is put specifically in terms of preventing and settling industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration. If one takes out of the objects any reference to conciliation and arbitration we regard that as undesirable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also takes the view that the prime purpose of the objects, at least, is to reflect the view that the primary head of constitutional power should be the conciliation and arbitration power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a sense this small amendment does bring out the difference between the Opposition and the Government on the whole approach to this Bill. The primary source of there being no conflict, of there being no disputes, should be the fact that employers and employees have the capacity to resolve their differences by direct agreement. In a perfect world we would not have a conciliation and arbitration commission because parties would be able to organise themselves without the need for external intervention. Accepting that we do not have a perfect world, the truth is that most successful enterprises, as much as possible, manage their affairs directly and avoid industrial disputes, not by rushing off to the Commission, to the union or to the Employers Federation but by sensible dealings-direct dealings-between employer and employee. That is central to our concern about the approach of the Government to industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government approaches industrial relations from the point of view of those agencies which have been created to perform some functions in the system, instead of approaching them from the point of view of wanting the basic system of employment to work of its own accord as far as possible. In other words, as in so many areas in this Bill, the emphasis is on external mechanisms, instead of the parties themselves. We think that is destructive. We think it is wrong. We believe that if the Government were consistent in its approach to developing a more internationally competitive, efficient, productive economy and a different, more productive culture in this country, again to use words that Senator Button has popularised--

TALK.START.PARA: —Immortalised.

—No, he has popularised them. That is something of an achievement. I say that in a positive way. Getting people to accept the idea that we need to approach things from the point of view of working more productively together is a sensible approach. That approach will be enhanced if the Government minimises the interference of external agencies as far as possible and if, as far as possible, it encourages employers and employees to work closely together. This amendment, again, is a fairly small amendment. In our view, the words that the Government is saying it wishes to retain puts entirely the wrong emphasis on the system. It is a diversion from the real task in hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to move the first part of amendment No. 4, which would insert a new paragraph in the objectives, paragraph (ba), to encourage adherence to the rule of law in industrial relations. The reason I want to move this part of the amendment separately from the other three objects, which are part of the circulated amendment, is that the other three objects essentially go to our amendments with respect to trade union structure. For the purposes of debate, it would be better if they were debated in conjunction with the later amendments which go to the structure of trade unions in this country. Do the Government and the other participants in the Committee have any problem with giving leave?
—There is no need for leave. The honourable senator is entitled to move his amendment as he likes.

—I am suggesting to the Minister that paragraphs (bb), (bc) and (bd), which are part of the fourth amendment, should be dealt with under order of debate No. 11, where there is a significant number of amendments which go to trade unions. Does the Minister have any problem with that?
—No.
—Since there is no objection, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, after paragraph 3 (b), insert the following new paragraph:
`(ba) to encourage adherence to the rule of law in industrial relations;'

The existing object is to provide for the observance and enforcement of agreements and awards made for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. This amendment was moved because, in the view of the Opposition, the Commission should also act to ensure that other laws relevant to industrial relations are adhered to. There are, of course, other laws-the common law itself, the Trade Practices Act, the criminal law, and so on.

We believe it is necessary to say that because there are documented examples of the Commission actually undermining the law in its activities. I do not suggest that that is a broad or common practice, but the particular case which achieved very great notoriety was a case of gross infringement of human rights. I refer to the situation of the Gibbins family, a husband and wife firm which operated a transport business involved in carrying livestock. If I can give the facts of that case it will become very clear why we needed an amendment of this sort. I shall quote from an article written by Mr Barry Purvis and his account of the Gibbins case because it is the quickest way that I can put it before the Senate. As he described it, the essential facts are that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union blacklisted certain carriers of livestock because they had crossed picket lines in order to deliver live sheep to ships for export. The blacklisted drivers and trucks were prevented from delivering livestock, either for farmers or for Thomas Borthwick and Sons to Borthwick's abattoir. This caused inconvenience and loss to the company, to 30 carriers and to 22 primary producers. As a result, the company took action against the union under the Trade Practices Act and the dispute was ultimately dealt with in the Arbitration Commission under the chairmanship of the Deputy President.

The Gibbins couple who were conducting this transport business were not a party to what occurred, and unfortunately they had their rights traded away in the course of the settlement of this dispute. The terms of settlement between the meat company and the union included the following statement:

It is accepted that for many and varied reasons put by the union and for valid commercial reasons, the company feels it necessary, if things are to become normal at its Brooklyn and Portland works, that for industrial relations reasons those people known to the company not to be invited or engaged to come on to the work nor will the company or any of its agents require members of the union to attend those known persons.

As I said, the Gibbins, in common with the other carriers involved, had no knowledge of the closed conciliation proceedings. They were not able to be present. The effect of this was to exclude them from carrying on their business in so far as it involved carrying on business with that firm. The Deputy President was the person acting under the Act. He is an official appointed to a public position, paid for by the public purse, and supposedly, one would think, administering the law in a way which paid regard to the rule of law and to the fair treatment of every citizen. In a confidential written statement which recorded settlement, the Deputy President said this:

I should note that the drivers who are involved in this matter have neither appeared nor shown any interest in the proceedings before me. However, I would hope that persons who may not benefit by this resolution and desire to do so would be able to put themselves into a position where their differences were resolved with the employees at Portland consistent with the resolution of the dispute and that this should happen as soon as practical.
The file containing the agreement has a statement by the Deputy President in which he said:
I am prepared to say that what has been reported to me as a resolution of the dispute could only be regarded as proper in the circumstances and I recommend it.

Happily, this matter got into the courts. It is very often the case, of course, that people are treated in a pretty shameful way in this country in the course of the settlement or the carrying out of industrial disputes and they are either unable to do anything about it or, in some cases, too frightened to do anything about it. When this case got before the courts the Federal Court declared illegal the agreement to blacklist the Gibbins partnership and other drivers affected. I want to quote from the judgment of Mr Justice Smithers in the Federal Court of Australia. This is how he described the agreement between the union and the company, that is, an agreement to settle a dispute which was ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The judge said that it:

. . . represented a complete surrender to the Union demand that because certain carriers carried on their lawful occupation by carrying live sheep to the ships their occupation as carriers to abattoirs should be destroyed. That surrender was made at the expense of the absent persons affected thereby and one can only wonder how that aspect of the matter could be proper. The reference to the lack of interest shown by `others who are involved in this matter' failed to recognise the fact that those others were in complete ignorance of the proceedings. The final sentence is obscure and appears to be directed to persons who will never be informed of it. The only meaning to be attributed to it is that it is a declaration that if carriers decide to do business with Borthwicks they must cease to carry stock to the ships in the Middle Eastern trade. The reference to persons subject to this policy, as persons `who may not benefit' from the proposed resolution of the dispute, is a naive and ingenuous description of persons who are to suffer in their livelihood by being directly excluded from the ordinary exercise of one aspect of their lawful occupation.

That is what Mr Justice Smithers had to say about an agreement which I suspect people in this chamber might well defend. I see in the chamber a senator from Queensland who thinks that, at times, we are too critical of trade unions. I ask him, if he wishes to enter this debate, whether he defends that sort of behaviour which is an attack not on the rights of some bloated capitalist but on the livelihood of a husband and wife carrying out a trucking business. If he had anything to do with people in the trucking business he would know that those people do not exactly have it easy. So the concerns that underlie our desire to have an objective which shows that it is the job of the Commission to encourage adherence to the rule of law and industrial relations are, in our view, justified.

Let me go back to what Mr Justice Smithers had to say in talking about how the Arbitration Commission had resolved the problem created by the union's retaliatory action against innocent livestock carriers going about their lawful business. Mr Justice Smithers said:

Borthwicks also agreed that persons other than those who had involved themselves in the process of conciliation should `respect the need not to cause further provocation' and therefore, Borthwicks `accepted the fact' that stock carriers who did not recognise the Union's picket lines over live sheep were not accepting the spirit of conciliation and would see those persons as an antagonistic factor to a continuing resolution of the industrial relations problem and would not invite or engage such people to come onto the works or require the members of the Union to be involved with such people.

Of course, Borthwick said, `We only did this', and I suppose that Borthwicks was not proud of what it had done-driving those people out of business. Borthwick said, `We acted under duress'. Again honourable senators opposite might say that that is rubbish; that unions never act like that; that they do not force people to force other people out of business. I invite some response. I ask whether the Government defends that sort of situation. Does the Government deny that it occurs? In this case, it was wrapped up with an exercise of jurisdiction by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. This is a situation where the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission failed to protect the clear legal rights of Jim and Marlene Gibbins, who are two of the few people put in this situation who got into court and asserted their rights successfully. This is the difficulty in conducting this debate, which principally involves encouraging wholesome, decent and positive relationships between employers and employees. That is where the future of this country lies.

I would agree very overtly with the honourable senator opposite that there are tens of thousands of trade unionists in this country who want precisely the same objective as I would seek. However, it is a concern for many Australians that a minority of people are prepared not to use the trade union power that they have but to abuse it. I have cited one quite specific example, and we could go on talking about that in this debate if it was thought to be fruitful. One of the things that is wrong with this country is that mechanisms which are put in place for the best possible reasons, to protect the rights and interests of the working men and women of Australia-mechanisms which we would certainly support; and certainly we support the interests of the working men and women of Australia-can be abused. As this case shows, the Commission itself, in its pursuit of the settlement of disputes, can even ride roughshod over the rights of people. Here in Canberra it was said recently that an industrial dispute could be settled by paying a crane driver something between $20,000 and $30,000 in which event he would leave town. That is the sort of seamy underside, if you like, of industrial relations. In my view it is something which should not be defended by honourable senators opposite. They should share the Opposition's repugnance to that element of industrial relations, and they should be prepared to support amendments which make it quite clear that in this area of Australian life, as in other areas of Australian life, the rule of law applies, and it applies to everybody. It applies to employers who should be brought to book if they abuse the legal rights of their employees and, of course, the records of the Commission are full of actions which have had to be taken against employers who have not met their obligations under awards.

We totally support the proposition that the rule of law must apply to employers, but we also believe that it must apply to unions. I am glad that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce quoted the report of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, because in this context we should remember the disgusting paragraph in that report which suggests that, while the rules apply to other Australians, trade unions are too powerful to be bound by the law. That is nonsense, it is wrong and it is repugnant to a free society, and it has been proved to be wrong over recent years. I commend the Opposition's amendment, and I think it would be extraordinary if the Australian Democrats found that they were unable to support the proposition that one of the objectives of our system should be to encourage adherence to the rule of law in industrial relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to respond. As far as I am aware, based on my experience in the trade union movement and in the community generally, the rule of law does apply. I think that Senator Chaney has demonstrated that by telling us about the outcome of a case in a higher court and the reasons for it. The fact is that there will always be a conflict of interest while there are those who, to use a cold objective term, exploit and those who are exploited. Of course, to some people the word `exploit' does not present an horrendous picture. It may simply be a description of the extent to which one person has a reasonable advantage over another. History is riddled with cases of simple workers, trying to provide a reasonable standard of living for their families, being disadvantaged by employers whose greatest concern has been to maximise profits, with no concern for those who suffer as a result of their behaviour. It has been clearly shown that laws have been made to suit the rich and not the poor. Satisfaction in the law has not been available to those people who could not afford to pay for it. Companies, large and small, have the resources to take advantage of recourse to law.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney talked about the problem associated with a transport company. Obviously, that company in law has the right to hire and fire. It is true that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the State and Federal area has the right-not in all areas, but more recently in Federal areas-to order reinstatement. It has always had the right to recommend reinstatement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has nothing to do with it.

—Yes it does have something to do with it. Senator Chaney was talking about a transport company and its livelihood and its right to operate a business. I talk about the right of an employee to earn a living so that his wife and family can be clothed and fed. I can recall an incident when a shop steward from a shipyard in Brisbane was dismissed. The sole reason was that he was the shop steward when a large number of disputes occurred. To my knowledge, he recommended against stoppages on many occasions. I represented him in the Arbitration Commission. My description to the Commission of the disadvantages his dismissal would put on his family was not considered. That company did not care. I do not know the company Senator Chaney talks about, but I suggest that it might have wanted to maximise profits, it might have had no concern for its employees, and it might have dismissed an employee to maximise profits if it suited it. Obviously the union was trying to protect its members' jobs. The transport company probably wanted to protect its profit and its future. The union was trying to protect the future of its members and the employees of that company because sending live animals overseas means that jobs are lost.

SPEECH.PARA: In making those comments I am not suggesting that people do not have a right by law in this country to send live animals overseas. That is a commercial decision. It affects a company in terms of its profits and it affects people in terms of the jobs that are lost. But that is an industrial struggle and, in this instance, it would have been waged in good faith. Australians, depending on what their interests are, will make a judgment on that. I do not propose to do so. If the union was carrying out the wishes of its members and trying to help them, I would defend its position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if they are breaking the law?

—I think Senator Chaney would know that many laws made in this country, and in other countries throughout the world, were considered to be good and fair at the time. For instance, the Tolpuddle Martyrs were sent out here for seven years because they had the hide to demand the same rate of pay from their employer as was being paid to other labourers in the district. The law said that they could be transported to Australia away from their families, for seven years. Is that the sort of law that Senator Chaney wants? I think he would still want that sort of law, but it is not possible to return to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I drive on the left hand side of the road. That is a good law. I observe that law because I think it is correct. I do not go to my neighbour's place to steal his property because I do not want him to do that to me. That is a good law. But I make no apology to anybody for saying that if my family were hungry and others had more food than they needed I would take that food to feed my family if that was the only way I could do so and there was not an honest living to be made. There are good laws and there are bad laws. Some bad laws have to be broken to be changed. I am prepared to take a stand on that and if society judges me on it I will accept it, but it will not prevent me from struggling for what is fair and equitable. The difference between law and justice is great. If Senator Chaney does not know that, he has a closed mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on the Opposition's fourth amendment to clause 3. I suggested earlier that there is not much point in having a long and protracted debate on some of these clauses. However, Senator Chaney has teased me into the debate to make a couple of points. It strikes us as being a statement of the obvious and we think it is an unnecessary insertion in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I am teased by what appears to be the beginning of a contradiction in Senator Chaney's logic between the arguments he advanced in relation to deleting `conciliation and arbitration' from an earlier clause and inserting `the rule of law' in this clause. It struck me that he was saying earlier that in essence in the whole area of industrial relations we should emphasise direct negotiation between employer and employee. That again is a statement of the obvious. That is the very starting point of industrial relations. But assuming that that fails, we follow up with proven processes of conciliation and arbitration. I am sensing the beginning of a contradiction here that on the one hand we want to back off the regulatory process of conciliation and arbitration and leave it to direct negotiation but, on the other hand, in this clause, we want to emphasise by the inserting of the obvious a final dependence upon an umpire, a court of law, a judge or a referee. I sense that there is a contradiction there.

In stating our position it seems to me that the expression `the rule of law' is almost a slogan-it is nice sounding, it conveys a million things that are good and it is not all that specific.
