SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not fully familiar with the case study Senator Chaney described. In accepting his description of it at face value, the Government certainly does not condone what happened. One could best say that one allies oneself with the view of Mr Justice Smithers on the matter. While those sorts of things are not to be condoned one wonders about the value of this amendment in the present legislation. As Senator McLean has said, in perhaps a different way, all individuals and organisations in Australia are required to observe the law.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no justification for singling out, unless it is on the basis of ideological assumptions, the area of industrial relations to include a reference to the rule of law and the objectives of this legislation. For example, one could cite numerous cases of similar iniquities to the ones Senator Chaney described as a result of the inadequate operation of the marketplace in commercial transactions. I do not want to go into it here but the trade practices legislation does not work in respect of a number of industries where monopoly power is exercised to the detriment of small producers. There is no reference in the trade practices legislation, as I recall, enjoining that Commission to have regard to the rule of law, no should there be here.

The other point is that the expression `rule of law' is deceptively simple. It embraces both practical considerations and philosophical concepts emerging from the field of jurisprudence and has no precise legal meaning. Frankly, I do not see what it will add to the legislation, and we regard it as unnecessary. Although it is a nice way of floating a concept of which we might all approve in principle and in the abstract, its relevance and purpose in this clause are not obvious to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the comments made by all three speakers on this amendment. Senator Burns seemed to have totally misunderstood the facts in the example that I gave. I was not talking about some employee being dismissed by a transport company, but about a husband and wife who were operating a small business and who were, in the terms of an industrial agreement between a large company and a large union, excluded from carrying on their business without any knowledge on their part. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was a party to that agreement in the sense that it endorsed the terms of settlement which included that gross infringement of the rights of those individuals. The fact that it was an infringement of their rights was subsequently demonstrated in the Federal Court, there is no question about that. It was settled by the judgment of Mr Justice Smithers. Senator Burns expressed his sympathy for people's right to earn a living. That is precisely what is being defended in this case-the right of a couple who do not have an employer to pay a weekly wage, but who have to earn their wage week by week by carrying on business, losing that right to earn a living. That is precisely the point that I was addressing.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a disturbing element in Senator McLean's comment when he suggested that the rule of law can be regarded as something of a slogan in these circumstances. Senator Button went on to say that he could not see any value in this amendment, that everybody is required to obey the law and why single out the industrial relations system. The reason for singling it out is that it is glaringly one of those areas of Australian life where breaches of the law, breaches of people's rights, are excused in the name of their being part of some industrial relations performance. One does not have to spend very much time going round talking to people who carry on business, particularly at the small business end of the spectrum, before one finds people who have been treated oppressively, very often illegally, but who feel that they are without a remedy. That is an existing severe practical problem.

The case that I quoted of the trucking couple who actually got justice in the Federal Court can be matched by many other examples. One has only to read the judgment of the Victorian Supreme Court in the Dollar Sweets case to appreciate the treatment of a truck driver by his fellow workers. He was dragged from his truck, pushed to the ground, beaten and suffered permanent injury. These activities took place in the course of a so-called industrial dispute. It is not good enough for Senator Button or indeed Senator McLean to say that of course the law applies, and does it not prove the case as the person in question finished up in court. There are many cases where that does not occur. But much more significant is the fact that the Commission, as I indicated in the Portland Transport case, has been involved in what was a breach of the legal rights of a citizen and in a secret way.

This Government has appointed Professor Hancock of the Arbitration Commission, an uncriticised appointment as I recall it. Professor Hancock has had a distinguished academic career and has a great knowledge of industrial relations. He is one of the authors of the Hancock report of the Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, the report on which this industrial legislation is supposedly based. I referred in general terms in my speech in support of this amendment to the statement which was made by the Hancock Committee headed by His Honour Mr Justice Hancock, who is currently a Deputy President of the Commission, and he talks about the application of the law in industrial relations. In paragraph 10.293 of the report, having canvassed in the previous paragraphs the question of compliance with arbitral decisions and all the rest of it, he made the following observations. I shall read the whole paragraph because it is fundamentally important in explaining why this positive affirmation of the fact that the Commission must look to the rule of law is needed. Professor Hancock and his colleagues on the Hancock Committee said:

Related to these considerations is a fourth: the analogy with civil litigants and sporting contestants ignores a major ingredient of the industrial relations scene-the phenomenon of power. If we ask why litigants and sportsmen usually accept the adjudicators' decisions, we find part of the answer in the ethics accepted by the disputants; but part, too, lies in their relative weakness. The two factors are interrelated: the ethic of accepting decisions gains strength from the difficulty of doing otherwise. By contrast, trade unions are, to varying degrees, centres of power: they replace the powerlessness of individual workers with collective strength. It is a mistaken view of the pluralistic society to assume that every `subject' is equally dominated by the might of the state and its arms of enforcement. Some may wish that things were different: but vain hopes are no basis for effective policy.

What Professor Hancock and his colleagues are saying is that one cannot expect trade unions to have to obey the law like other Australians because they are too powerful. I utterly reject that. To have people in this Parliament say that one does not have to worry about the rule of law because it applies, when somebody that this Government has appointed to the Commission is a party to that statement to the extent to which the law applies, seems to me to be a logical absurdity.

One of the positive things that have happened in industrial relations in the last decade is that the lie which developed following the gaoling of Clarrie O'Shea-and I do not know anyone who would see the gaoling of Clarrie O'Shea or anybody else as a sensible industrial remedy these days, if ever-is that unions cannot be made to obey the law as they are too powerful. That lie actually found its way into a report which has been warmly commended by this Government. This report may contain much that is valuable, but I totally condemn the craven, undemocratic and wrong attitude reflected in that paragraph. We have a situation where somebody who is charged with the administration of this area of the law has expressed that as his view. It simply is not good enough. Australians are entitled to be treated equally and are entitled to see their legal rights upheld. I do not want to see a situation where it requires the banding together of a mass of people, as happened in Melbourne in the Dollar Sweets case, where the Chamber of Commerce rallied its members to support that beleaguered businessman, Fred Stauder, who ran a little lolly factory. That case uncovered not just the oppression of a man who was trying to make a living in his business. It uncovered the oppression of worker by worker.

Senator Burns-and I see that he has gone again-came into the chamber and complained about my attitude to trade unions. He bleated that he believes he should defend the right of people to work. I will be impressed by that when Senator Burns comes in here and defends the right of the chefs who were dismissed by this Parliament from their jobs because they would not join a trade union. I do not know whether Senator Burns is worried about their wives and children. The hypocrisy and cant in these debates are pathetic. The truth is that the Minister at the table--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you defending?

—I have never defended illegal conduct by employers, and I never will. I point to the fact that, as Mr Willis said last year, the problem is that there is a lack of enforcement procedures in this area of the law. He did not say that employers who breach awards cannot be brought to book. Senator Button would know that in the reports of the Commission one will find plenty of evidence of the imposition of the rule of law on employers who do not play the game. Of course, that should happen. I support the existence of trade unions so that oppressive employers can be stopped. Of course, there will be oppressive employers, just as there will be oppressive elements of the trade union movement. Nobody is arguing that there should be some lopsided approach to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Minister that his answer to me is specious. It is sophistry to suggest that we do not need to be concerned about the rule of law in the area of industrial relations because everybody is bound by the law. That is not a fact in this country. This is not the only area of deficiency. I will join the Government in pursuing other areas of deficiency as they are uncovered. This is one of the notorious areas of deficiency in this country. In the last 10 years, with the use of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, it has been demonstrated that powerful unions can be made to obey the law in the same way that other people obey it. Senator Button would know that his mate from the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party, George Crawford, his fellow endorsed Labor candidate and parliamentarian, led the plumbers and gasfitters during month after month of guerilla warfare against the building industry in that long-running dispute that was so ineptly handled, in the sense that the Commission was so slow to come to grips with the abuse of its procedures and of employers and fellow trade unionists by the Crawford-led plumbers and gasfitters. But when the law was finally used, an injunction against illegal conduct obtained, the injunction breached and a penalty of $280,000 imposed, suddenly the rule of law did apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the law was exercised.

—Exactly. The Minister knows that in many circumstances people do not have the capacity, the economic strength, to protect their rights. How many people such as the truck driver couple that I described are in a position to protect themselves? Mr Stauder of Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd could not have protected himself without the aid, comfort and financial assistance of the Chamber of Commerce in Victoria; there is no question about that. Is the Minister defending a situation in which it is exceptional for the person whose rights are abused to get that sort of relief? That is the exceptional case, and the Minister knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Minister will tell us that in some way paragraph 10.293 has been purged from the thinking of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I do not think that it has. I have enough contact with people who are involved in industrial relations to believe that that sort of thinking, that abrogation of the rule of law, is still alive and well. I urge the Committee, which at times shows some capacity to consider these matters of principle, to adopt this amendment, because I believe that it is something that 95 per cent of the Australian people would support. There is no community support for the sort of actions that I have described in this debate; none at all. The Minister and the Government know that. It will be extraordinary if they cannot support the view that it is one of the objectives of our industrial relations system to encourage adherence to the rule of law in industrial relations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief, Senator Chaney is saying, `I can identify some examples of reprehensible conduct in the industrial relations arena'.
—You are suggesting they are very rare, are you?

—Let me finish. Senator Chaney is saying, `I can identify some examples of reprehensible conduct in the industrial relations arena. I can pluck out some phrases from the Hancock report which I do not like, and these things which I have done justify the amendment which I have moved. We will fix this up by putting in reference in the objectives of the Industrial Relations Act to adherence to the rule of law'. Senator Chaney will not fix it by doing that, and he knows it. He has not tried to fix it in any other legislation. He is trying to shift this debate onto a favourite ground of moral outrage.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned here with a piece of legislation and what the contents of a piece of legislation should be. There is no reason, as I said earlier, for singling out this legislation for particular consideration by including objectives such as this. Having said that, I still share much of Senator Chaney's concern about the incidents which have been described-incidents which become less and less frequent in the Australian industrial relations scene because the environment has changed because of the policies of this Government. That is what this legislation is about. It is about changing attitudes and environments; it is not about singling out particular instances forever. I agree with Senator Chaney with regard to the examples he gave, but they do not justify the amendment that he has moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion I, too, shall be brief. I note the Minister's statement that it will not be fixed in this legislation. Unfortunately, that is probably true, because the Government has indicated that it will oppose subsequent amendments which I intend to move, which would increase the capacity of the existing system of conciliation and arbitration to enforce its own directions. The sad fact is that the Government has set its face against that sort of improvement. I do not wish to anticipate the debate in that regard, but the reality is that this amendment simply provides the objectives which are, in themselves, a guide to the behaviour of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, or the new Industrial Relations Commission. Those objectives could be made quite explicit in this way, quite apart from the specific changes which could be made to the proposed Act to provide for enforcement.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say two things in that regard. Fourteen months ago Mr Willis was clearly saying that that sort of change was required. When we introduced a private member's Bill to give the Commission the power to issue directions and procedures which would then flow which would require people to follow those directions, the Metal Trades Industry Association indicated that it thought they were eminently practical, workable and usable. I mention the Metal Trades Industry Association because it is important to note that that Association is at the forefront of promoting award restructuring, which the Minister would see as being one of the great white hopes of better industrial relations and a more productive set of workplaces in Australia. It is not at all incompatible with the move towards better industrial relations to have a system in which there are binding rules.

The simple fact is that in those countries that the Ministers of this Government and the trade union movement point to as models and, in particular, those European countries where there is a strong involvement by the trade union movement in the work force-in Sweden, Germany, and so on-one will find that there are methods of binding trade unions to the law which certainly succeed in a way in which they do not succeed in Australia. The reality is that those countries which are seen as models have effective compliance with the rule of law as part of their system of industrial relations. In that sense Australia is an odd man out. I find it extraordinary that the Government should resist a simple statement of principle as a guide to its Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one or two brief points. I am conscious of the fact that I am debating this matter with two lawyers. I would like to pass a comment about the law as such. Senator Chaney is suggesting to the Committee that the rule of law should prevail. The Australian Democrats are not opposing that suggestion. I say that it is obviously true in relation to all law. Senator Burns qualified it a little by saying that his position essentially is that the rule of good law should prevail and that citizens might even feel a moral obligation to oppose laws which they consider to be bad laws. That raises an interesting and quite legitimate variation to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As a non-lawyer I would like to make the observation that one's confidence in the law, of course, can take a battering. Over the last few years in this country we have witnessed some extraordinary examples. Senator Chaney has cited an example which he described, in his words, as `a notorious case of deficiency' and one can only agree, according to the case that he cited, that it was notoriously deficient. I could perhaps cite the Chamberlain case and say that we saw the legal procedure in train-and in train over a period of years and in a number of different jurisdictions-but the outcome of it was not justice. In fact it was a travesty of justice. These arguments are all relative. In the final analysis of course, we have to have confidence in the process in which we are taking part. I think that ultimately we must agree that the rule of law prevails. We are simply saying that it is implied, understood irrevocably and there is nothing to be gained by pretending otherwise as law makers. There will always be, to use Senator Chaney's words again, `a notorious case of deficiency'. There will always be, to use my words, `notorious cases of injustice'. I think we should get on with the business of making laws.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 8, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``public sector employment'', line 30, after ``but'' insert ``, other than in section 121,''.
(2) Page 54, subclause 121 (1), line 25, after ``award'', insert ``or order''.

(3) Page 54, subclause 121 (2), definition of ``relevant law'', paragraph (a), lines 34 to 35, leave out ``Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971'', insert ``Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988''.

These amendments moved by the Government relate to the operation of clause 121 of the Bill. They are designed to make the operation of the clause more effective and ensure that the statutory powers under the clause are more in line with the scheme presently in operation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904.

Perhaps I should explain briefly the background of clause 121. That provision is framed to support the effective operation of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's jurisdiction over industrial issues and disputes in the Commonwealth and Territory public sectors. This is achieved by empowering the Commission to make awards that are not in accord with certain laws of the Commonwealth and a Territory. Without such a provision, the Commission could be prevented from making awards which supplement or update standards in Commonwealth or Territory legislation relating to public sector employment or, alternatively, which resolve disputes in areas of employment governed by determinations made pursuant to such legislation by public sector employees and relating to the terms and conditions of employment of staff-for example, determinations made under section 82d of the Public Service Act 1922.

I turn to the amendments. Amendment No. 1 amends the definition of public sector employment in subclause 4 (1). That is necessary because subclause 121 (1) confers award-making powers in relation to an industrial dispute involving `public sector employment'. The difficulty is that certain categories of employment or service can be prescribed by regulation out of the definition of public sector employment. The purpose of so prescribing such employment or service is not to remove it from the operation of subclause 121 (1); instead, it is designed to remove it from the scope of clause 5, which gives the Commission wider jurisdiction in relation to various areas of work, including public sector employment. Without the amendment there may be circumstances where the Commission cannot resolve a dispute by making an award. To avoid that result, the amendment preserves the operation of clause 121 in respect of employment or service which may be prescribed out of the scope of the term public sector employment.

Amendment No. 2 corrects an omission in the drafting. To be consistent with the schemes used throughout the Bill, there should be a reference to an order of the Commission as well as to an award. Amendment No. 3 updates the references in subclause 121 (2) to the legislation in respect of which the Commission may not make inconsistent awards or orders. The compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971 is to be repealed by the procla- mation of the relevant provisions in the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. That Act came partly into operation recently but it will not repeal the earlier Act until later this year.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 30, paragraph 63 (1) (c), line 8, after ``organisations'', insert ``, employers and employees''.

Clause 63 relates to the functions of the Australian Industrial Registry; that is, to keep a register of organisations and to act as the registry-as one would expect. The third subclause says it has the function of providing advice and assistance to organisations in relation to their rights and obligations under the Act. The amendment which I moved is to insert the words `employers and employees' after the word `organisation' so that one of the functions of the Industrial Registry would be:
to provide advice and assistance to organisations, employers and employees in relation to their rights and obligations under this Act.

The amendment we propose does not suggest that the Registry should not have the function of giving advice to organisations-by that I mean unions and employer organisations, who are important in terms of the functioning of the arbitration system. But the arbitration system does not impinge only on trade unions and employer organisations, the Confederation of Australian Industry and all those other bodies which are known to represent groups of employers. In fact, individual employers and employees also have rights and obligations under the Act. In the view of the Opposition, there is no reason why they also should not receive the same assistance. In other words, since the Act impinges directly on them, and not simply on them as people who are members of organisations, they ought to be as free to go to the Registry for advice and assistance as anybody else. Example of rights of individual employees under the Government's Bill include the rights concerning membership of organisations. In clauses 261, 263 and 265 of the Bill we see provisions which specifically relate to the rights of individuals. Clause 261 says, in part:

Subject to any award or order of the Commission, an employee who is eligible to become a member of an organisation of employees is, unless of general bad character, entitled, subject to payment of any amount properly payable in relation to membership:
(a) to be admitted as a member of the organisation; and
(b) to remain a member so long as the employee complies with the rules . . .

Senator Burns has come back into the chamber. I am sure he will be concerned to see the rights of employees who wish to be trade unionists-rights which are set out in this Bill-enforced. This would be consistent with the view he expressed earlier in the debate, about people's rights. There are other examples, such as the right to seek a direction that an organisation follow its own rules. The Government's Bill, in clause 209, provides that an individual may seek a direction, where he believes his organisation is not complying with the rules. That individual can be an employer or an employee. An employee who feels that his trade union is not following its rules can seek relief under clause 209. There are rights given to individuals concerning secret ballots relating to industrial action in clause 136.

I mention those things because this Bill continues the situation in which organisations are very important. In other words, groups of employers, under some mantle or other-perhaps the Confederation of Australian Industry-and groups of employees under the mantle of a union, have an important role under the scheme of things under the Act. But as we would expect, and indeed we would want, the position of individuals who are concerned with those organisations also receives attention. The simple objective here is to ensure that the Registry has a formal function not merely to advise organisations but also to advise individuals. It is true that the amendments we will be moving do try to extend further the rights of individuals under the Act. But I stress the point to the Committee that the existing Bill, the Bill which will go into law, has rights for individuals. We believe they should be able to get advice from the Registry on those rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is not accepted. There are some practical reasons for the Government's not accepting it, as well as some other reasons. There is a certain-I do not want to go overboard-rough logic about the Opposition's amendment in the light of some other amendments Senator Chaney has moved.
—Oh! High praise.
—There's a certain consistency, Senator Button.

—I would not be prepared to put it that high-not this morning; after lunch, perhaps. The amendment seems to reflect a desire to turn the Australian Industrial Registry into a version of the Industrial Relations Bureau, which was a failed creature of the Fraser Government. I do not think that is a sensible course. Senator Chaney himself has pointed out this morning how individual employers have benefited from the representative role which organisations of employers play in a variety of instances. Those employer organisations operate, as it were, outside the direct purview of the Commission. They are the privatised arm of the industrial relations system. They advise employers about their rights and so on and they will have access to the Industrial Registrar in respect of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: There are also a few practical reasons why we oppose this amendment. It could well involve the Registry in controversy where there are disputes between members and organisations. Many of the rights relate to the entitlement of members to bring proceedings against their organisations, some of the rights to which Senator Chaney referred. That is true on both sides, on the employer side and the employee side. I recall an example from my own experience. Some years ago the Victorian Employers Federation had a bitter, internecine dispute between its factions. I recall that they both sought advice from the Industrial Registrar and had to be sent away. The issues were ultimately resolved by the Industrial Registrar himself in pursuit of his statutory functions. So in many cases advice is more appropriately sought from sources other than the Registrar. The Bill makes financial assistance available for those purposes in matters involving litigation of one kind or another under the Act.

There is merit, as Senator Chaney points out, in individuals having advice available about their rights and obligations under the Bill. This advice can be expected to be available from several sources. The Government proposes to make material available explaining the Act in simple terms. Organisations, on both sides again, can make advice available. The Registrar and the Department of Industrial Relations will continue to assist individuals to seek advice about statutory rights and obligations. The Arbitration Inspectorate will continue to perform that function as well.

On balance, the amendment is not acceptable for the reasons I outlined earlier. The final reason why it is regarded as undesirable is its sheer impracticality. If the Industrial Registrar became a source of advice for any aggrieved employer and employee, I do not know how big it would be but it would be an enormous organisation potentially. That is not desirable. The resource implications have not been considered properly by the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that has been moved by Senator Chaney widens the functions of the Australian Industrial Registry to provide advice and assistance to employers and employees, as well as to registered organisations, in relation to their rights and obligations under the Act. As we know, the Bill establishes the Australian Industrial registry as a statutory authority. One of the functions given to the Registry is to provide advice and assistance to registered organisations in relation to their rights and obligations under the Act. But there is no reason, contrary to the comments of Senator Button, why the registry should provide help only to organisations. Individual employers and employees have rights and obligations under the Act. There is no reason for them not to have the same access to assistance as organisations are able to enjoy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill as drafted by the Government simply reinforces this Government's concept of the corporate state, its lack of recognition of the importance of individuals and their rights. This Government professes to be a democratic government, to be a champion of individual rights, to uphold and respect freedom of the individual. Yet the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill not only ignore the rights of individuals; they actively deny them.

We discussed earlier in the debate the rights of an individual worker to join or not to join a union, and to have a choice as to which organisation he wishes to join. So there are a number of ways in which this legislation denies the rights of individuals. More and more we see important national goals and decisions being determined by the powerful representatives of big government, big unions and big business under the corporate state mentality that has developed under this Government's administration. Therefore, it is important that the amendment moved by Senator Chaney with regard to the Industrial Registry be accepted by the Senate so that individual employers and employees, as well as organisations, will have the opportunity to seek advice and assistance from the Australian Industrial Registry. I support the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 38, clause 94, lines 30 to 35, leave out the clause.
This amendment leaves clause 94 out of the Bill. Clause 94 provides:

In determining an industrial dispute, the Commission shall, subject to section 95, provide, so far as possible and so far as the Commission considers proper, for uniformity throughout an industry carried on by employers in relation to hours of work, holidays and general conditions in the industry.

We seek to delete that provision because it is, I think, common ground with respect to the development and improvement of the economy that what is required is a more flexible economy rather than a more rigid one. Certainly at that level of generality I think one would get broad agreement. The concern of the Opposition is that, in a quite practical way, this sort of provision in the Bill will discourage productive flexibility. I will give a quite specific example of that in a few minutes.

We think this clause gives a negative signal at a time when we need a more flexible, enterprise-oriented system of industrial relations. We think that need for greater flexibility has been admitted, not just by the Opposition but by many people in the Government and, indeed, by people within the trade union movement. For example, last May, a few days after the May statement, Mr Keating was declaring that the last great area of change to be overcome was labour market reform. So Mr Keating, at that stage anyway, was putting this at the top of the agenda. He stated at that time that the policy objective was to create a flexible industrial relations system in which wages and conditions reflected the different levels of prosperity in different industries. It might be said that that statement is compatible with this clause because this clause does in fact refer to uniformity on an industry basis; but, in the view of the Opposition, that is too restrictive a view. If one looks at the actual economic task we face, in all of this debate one can accept that our common ground is to improve the value of the work of every Australian, to improve its productivity, to change it in ways that will not only make it more economically productive but also more satisfying personally. In our view, rigidities do not help to take us down that track.

There is inbuilt in the Australian psyche a liking for uniformity. One of the problems the Minister at the table faces in terms of the changes he is seeking to promote is that people are generally quite happy to continue down tried and true tracks. They do not necessarily want change; they are comfortable doing the same thing. In a world where change is endemic and where we have to become more competitive, that can be a very destructive attitude. It is part of that Australian attitude, I think, that people find irritating differences in prices between shops, even though that kind of price competition in a general sense is helpful to consumers and will in general give them a better deal. I am sure that is a quite important part of the way people respond in the community.

I understand this attraction to the idea that everyone who works in an industry should get the same sort of treatment. The trouble is that that attitude ultimately is destructive of the delivery of improved results and hence the higher living standards we want. I was going back through a paper that Charles Fitzgibbon gave in February 1986 on the evolving nature of industrial relations in this country. There were two papers, one to the Productivity Council and one to the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC), which attracted a lot of attention in that year. This is the paper he prepared for EPAC. I am sure the Minister would have read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before he gave it.
—I hope the Minister is not going to claim that he wrote it.
—No, not at all.
—I record for the benefit of Hansard that the Minister does not make that claim. At paragraph 81 Mr Fitzgibbon said this:

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it necessary to build in a method of overcoming rigidities?

For those few people who might read this Hansard and the few people who are listening to this debate, perhaps I can say that Mr Fitzgibbon came from a trade union background. He was an Australian Council of Trade Unions Vice President and the head of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. That is his working background. He goes on:

It is quite clear that in any complex society such as ours a rigidity which prevents a reward for special endeavour will inevitably mean that there is generally no special endeavour. Very few sections of the overall population are so imbued with their responsibility to the community generally that they will produce special effort for no reward. That is shown in instance after instance in industry. If a method of overcoming that rigidity can be developed which does not affect the overall community except in a good way, that is by introducing more endeavour and more wealth, then it is in the overall interest of the community to allow that flexibility and to eschew the rigidity that prevents the flexibility from developing.

Mr Fitzgibbon has a great way with words. That is a very sensible statement, as indeed was most of what was said in that paper. It makes sense to people from all parts of the political spectrum and to both employers and trade unionists.

In a practical sense, let me illustrate the sorts of difficulties which arise because of this approach of having an industry-wide approach. I pick a Queensland example, not to enrage or entice Senator Burns back into the debate but merely because it is an example which I think very squarely makes the point I wish to demonstrate. It refers to Sanctuary Cove. At Sanctuary Cove and multiplicity of people were employed under the usual multiplicity of award and conditions. Earlier this year the Queensland Industrial Commission agreed to make a new award covering all employees at Sanctuary Cove. The application for the award was made by the Queensland Confederation of Industry Ltd and was supported by the Queensland Trades and Labor Council. I am pleased to see Senator Burns nodding. This is a case where unions and employers both apparently felt that this was beneficial, so they sought a new single award to cover it. The application was supported by the Trades and Labor Council and a number of individual unions. It was unfortunately opposed by one union, the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union. I think that senator whose senior office-bearer was in that union has a lot to answer for. We will get on to that later.

The award was designed to replace 15 existing awards covering employees at the resort, all with their own classification structures and pay scales. The main argument for a common award was that it would make it far easier to move employees from one part of the resort to another and in particular to meet peaks in demand for labour. Another key element in what was agreed was the concept of a loaded hourly rate. Instead of being paid penalty rates for working evenings or weekends, employees would receive a standard hourly payment with a loading to compensate for not receiving penalty payments. In principle, no employee would receive lesser aggregate earnings than he would have received under a traditional award.

The Queensland Commission agreed to make that award and referred to the need to assist any measures that would enhance productivity and efficiency and give rise to the sort of flexibility that the hospitality and tourism industry in Australia has been seeking for many years. It was convinced of the need for such flexibility and that such flexibility could be obtained only through the award proposed. That is a classic illustration of what I understand the Minister supports in terms of award restructuring. It was being done on a particular site bringing together 15 disparate awards--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't start Senator Burns wanting to speak, otherwise he might outflank you on this.

—I would be delighted if he did. What has happened following that is that the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union has taken action to have the State award overruled by the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and it has sought to rope into the Federal award the employer at Sanctuary Cove. When I last checked, the matter had not been determined; if it has, I will be delighted to be told during the debate. I hope that the application has been unsuccessful. SPEECH.PARA: Some would regard them as brave new concepts, whilst others I feel sure would use a different objective to describe them.

This concept is one which could have wide repercussions not only throughout the hospitality industry in particular, but throughout industry as a whole. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to Senator Burns, I support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Chaney to clause 94. The Sanctuary Cove example, of which Senator Chaney gave specific details, reinforces the need for the amendment. I will refer to that case again in detail in a few minutes. The amendment Senator Chaney has moved deletes the requirement of clause 94 of the Bill, which is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commission shall . . . provide, so far as possible and so far as . . . proper, for uniformity throughout an industry . . . in relation to hours of work, holidays and general conditions.

The clause as it stands gives precisely the wrong signal at a time when we need a more flexible enterprise-oriented system of industrial relations. The need for such flexibility has been recognised even by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he declared, in his speech to the National Press Club after the mini-Budget, that labour market reform was `the last great area of change to be overcome'. Yet it is clauses such as clause 94 as put forward in this Bill that clearly indicate that the Government is not proceeding with any worthwhile reform; it is simply retaining the existing system under a new piece of legislation, under a new name.

Reform of the industrial relations system in Australia is our single most important issue. The rigidities and coercion involved in the present system and which, as I have said, this Bill does nothing to change, are inconsistent with liberalism and are particularly detrimental to the interest of small States such as South Australia, which I represent. Small States require greater labour market flexibility to enable them to compete on interstate and overseas markets.

The concept of comparative wage justice with wage determinations and conditions determination in one sector of industry flowing on to other sectors and individual enterprises, irrespective of their capacity to pay, hinders economic growth. Wage determination must be based on a combination of national productivity and Australia's international competitiveness with the individual capacity to pay at the enterprise level. Highly profitable enterprises should share those profits with the employees who have assisted to create them, but less profitable enterprises should not be sent broke by being saddled with wage structures that they cannot afford. This requires a more decentralised system of wage determination to allow direct negotiations and agreements to be reached between employers and employees acting at the enterprise level. This legislation will not allow that greater flexibility to be achieved.

Of course, the absurdity and inflexibility of the current system, which this clause will entrench, is exemplified by the attempt to make a common award covering all employees at the Sanctuary Cove tourist resort. Senator Chaney has referred to this and I would like to refer to it in some detail. Earlier this year the Queensland Industrial Commission agreed to make a new award covering all employees at Sanctury Cove. The application for the award was made by the Queensland Confederation of Industry and was supported by the Queensland Trades and Labor Council and a number of individual unions. It was opposed by one union and one union only-the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union. The purpose of the award was to replace 15 existing awards covering various employees at the resort, all with their own classification structures and pay scales. Obviously, with a common award it would make it far easier to move employees from one part of the resort to another, in particular, to meet peaks in demand for labour and to allow the development of multiskilling which is of such great importance to Australia's future productivity.

Another key element in this new award was the concept of a loaded hourly rate. Instead of being paid penalty rates for working evenings or weekends, employees would receive a standard hourly payment with a loading to compensate for not receiving penalty payments. In principle, no employee would receive lesser aggregate earnings than he would have received under a traditional award. One of the principles which bedevils our system of industrial relations and our wage cost structure is this concept of penalty rates. Here we have an opportunity to do away with penalty rates, at no loss to the individual employees concerned, and to get a more rational remuneration structure. That is why the Queensland Commission agreed to make this award-referring to the need to assist any measure which would enhance productivity and efficiency and give rise to the sort of flexibility that the hospitality and tourism industry in Australia has been seeking for so many years, so that it can generate the wealth and income for this country of which it is capable as one of our main growth industries. Of course, that potential has been hindered for so many years by our archaic industrial relations structure and our methods of wage determination and our determination of other conditions of employment. So the Commission was convinced of the need for flexibility and that that flexibility could be obtained only through the award proposed. However, the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union has taken action to have this State award overruled in the Federal Commission. It has sought to rope the employer at Sanctuary Cove into the Federal Hotels and Retail Liquor Industry Award 1983. Senator Chaney mentioned earlier that the issue has not yet been finalised. However, on 22 June 1988 Commission Bain rejected a 41 (1) (d) application by the employer that the Federal Commission should refrain from further hearing the union's claim on the ground that the matter was properly being dealt with by the Queensland Industrial Commission. So the liquor union has at least made it that far in obstructing the application of this new rational award. Commissioner Bain's decision was rather sceptical of the concepts of the loaded hourly rate and the common award and, in fact, he said:
Some would regard them as brave new concepts, whilst others I feel sure would use a different adjective to describe them.

This is the sort of outdated thinking that we see in some of our industrial tribunals. Here we see an award made which will benefit all employees, which will benefit this project and will indeed benefit the nation through the income and wealth that will be generated in our tourism industry, yet because of this outdated thinking we see delays in the award coming into being.

Commissioner Bain's attitude to the special loading is consistent with the approach that says that conditions should be uniform throughout an industry, and the old outdated concept of comparative wage justice. If we are to develop our future potential for economic growth in this country, we must do away with that concept because, as I have said, we must have a system of wages and conditions determination which reflects conditions at the individual enterprise level. Commissioner Bain also claimed:

This concept is one which could have wide repercussions not only through the hospitality industry in particular, but throughout industry as a whole. For this reason alone, I am of the opinion that in this matter the question of public interest is of such magnitude that it should not be determined in the narrow context of an award covering only one site of operation in what is clearly a national industry.

Certainly, it does have wide repercussions but we do need, as the Opposition says time and again, to get to an enterprise level determination of wages and conditions. Therefore, it is quite appropriate for this award to have been made by the Queensland Industrial Commission. We need to have these repercussions flow right through the Australian economy and Australian industry so that we can get rid of this nonsense idea of comparative wage justice so that we can have wages and conditions determined at individual enterprise level according to the profitability of an individual enterprise.

We need to have a situation where profitable enterprises reward the employees who have contributed to that profitability, and where enterprises that are not doing so well, that have excessive cost structures and are not profitable, can reflect those difficulties in their wages and conditions determinations so that they have the opportunity to remain in business, remain competitive, and can continue to provide employment opportunities rather than having to go out of business and throw their employees on the employment scrapheap. Clauses 94 and 95 of this Bill will further entrench the absurdities that I have so graphically illustrated with respect to Sanctuary Cove, and indeed they will not allow us to get away from this outdated concept of comparative wage justice. That is why I strongly support Senator Chaney's amendments which, by considerably restricting the ability of the new industrial commission to impose uniformity of wages and to authorise flow-ons from certified agreements, will introduce much more flexibility into the system. That is what we need in Australia today.

Clause 94 of the Industrial Relations Bill provides uniformity in relation to certain conditions of employment. It will replace section 51 of the Act. I cannot recall exactly when section 51 was inserted but I think it was in the 1950s. It has been around for donkey's years. It is a section that has served the test of time. It is a section, it is worth noting, that has remained in the Act under successive governments and under successive Prime Ministers-successive conservative Prime Minister and successive conservative Ministers of labour in previous Federal governments. It has travelled through a period of Labor government in the 1970s and has remained in the Act under a high profile period for industrial relations in Australia, the period of the Fraser Government. It has remained unamended in all of that time.

I cannot help thinking that this debate is becoming a debate about the symbols, the images and the messages that parties wish to convey to the broader electorate in which, in an almost sloganeering way, the main differences between the industrial relations objectives the two major competing parties are presented. This provision is a machinery, mechanical, practical, down to earth, necessary provision that a bench like the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission requires to grease the day to day wheels of practical operations in industrial relations.
