SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would like to speak very briefly today about an historical event which I believe to be of world significance and which I was privileged to witness a few weeks ago. I was invited to witness the destruction of four SS22 missiles in the Soviet Union, the first concrete step in the implementation of the intermediate range nuclear forces (INF) agreement between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). I was invited not as a senator or a parliamentarian-in fact, I was the only foreign parliamentarian present-but as a representative from the Australian peace movement. The invitation came from the Soviet Peace Committee and I was one of 28 guests from 17 countries and several international peace organisations such as Pax Christi. Those countries are mainly European, both west and east: those in the immediate range of the superpowers' land-based missiles. But there were also representatives of the peace movements in Canada and the United States and from Egypt and India as well as myself. From the time of the first Gorbachev-Reagan summit the Soviet Peace Committee had been pressing its Government to allow representatives of the world peace movement to witness the first act of nuclear disarmament. The USSR Government allowed our presence at this first destruction of nuclear weapons in recognition of the role that the world peace movement has played in bringing about this historic first step. The overseas delegates later expressed the hope that the United States would also recognise the contribution of the peace movement by inviting a similar delegation to the initial act of destruction of its own missiles.

SPEECH.PARA: I was deeply honoured to have been invited to be a witness to the destruction of the missiles. After more than 40 years working in various ways for peace, it was a very exciting and moving experience to be present at this first concrete step towards real disarmament. I am going to describe very briefly what actually happened because I have found universal interest, sometimes in most unexpected quarters, since I returned to Australia. The actual explosion of the missiles and their launchers took place at Saryozek on the Kazakhstan steppes in the south-west corner of the USSR. We witnessed the destruction of four SS22 missiles on 1 August and from that time on eight missiles have been destroyed every day. Under the terms of the agreement the missiles themselves must be totally destroyed-nothing left-and the launchers reduced to scrap. These particular missiles had been brought to the demolition site from Czechoslovakia, from the German Democratic Republic and from other parts of the Soviet Union. We saw the stockpile of other missiles which will be destroyed over the coming months.

We arrived at the site several hours before the explosion took place and found what was almost a carnival atmosphere within the military area, which had been opened for the first time to the overseas visitors, to the United States inspection team and the world media, complete with cameras and tape recorders.

We were briefed at a Press conference where both the USSR and the United States military teams answered questions about the technical aspects of the event and its place in the disarmament process. We were entertained by local musicians and singers, some of us joined in the dancing and we were treated to local food. It was a festival atmosphere in celebration of what was about to happen and its significance as a step towards world peace. In the early afternoon we walked up a small hill from which we could see the missiles themselves just under two kilometres away in the valley. The warheads had been removed for later disposal, together with the guidance systems, in accordance with the INF agreement, so it was a breathtaking surprise to hear, as the countdown finished, a huge explosion and then to see an enormous red fireball with sparks shooting from it from which emerged a mushroom shaped cloud.

As I said, there were no warheads on the weapons, so the visual effect was purely symbolic and had a profound effect on those who were watching. We all broke into spontaneous applause and later conversation revealed that most of us had felt very deeply moved. Almost immediately it began to rain, which the locals believed to be a sign of good fortune. Local scientists and peace activists assured us that the demolition was ecologically safe, and indeed we were able to walk around the demolition site shortly afterwards and confirm that the missiles had totally disappeared: the largest piece of launcher debris was only about half a metre in length-a safe and efficient disposal job. The local people were clearly delighted with what was happening. As one poster we saw said, `Saryozek, launching place of disarmament'. Local people are planning to build a memorial on the site with the slogan, `Farewell to the armaments!'. Before I left Australia many people said they envied what they called `the chance of a lifetime'. I am deeply grateful to have had the chance of a thousand lifetimes to be present at this first concrete act of nuclear disarmament. I pay tribute to the USSR for recognising the role of the world peace movement in bringing this about, and I hope the United States Government will do likewise when it commences its missile destruction process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today not with any joy but to express to honourable senators some concerns I have about the implementation of the Aboriginal policy by this Government. I think we all acknowledge that Aboriginal Australians are a disadvantaged group in our community and we must do everything we can to remedy that situation as quickly as possible. However, the Government's policies for Aborigines, as they apply in the cases I am about to give, are causing more problems than they are solving. In fact, they are creating disharmony. I refer in particular to recent grants made by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in Mount Isa, Queensland, which have been brought to my attention by the State member for Mount Isa, Mr Peter Beard. The grants were so irresponsible and shortsighted that they were almost beyond belief. These grants have created subsidised employment for a few people-either Aboriginal or of Aboriginal descent-in Mount Isa, but it has been achieved at the expense of other business in that town and has created ill will and resentment between white and black Australians where none previously existed.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is a nutshell is this: Aborigines in Mount Isa recently, between May and July-and I have only two cases I can give-have been given grants and subsidies by the Department to set up their own business in direct competition with established business in Mount Isa, in a small closed community. If some study had been done on unmet demand and grants had been made and the businesses had been successful we would have all been pleased. However, that is not the case. The established businesses are unable to compete with the taxpayer subsidised businesses of the Aborigines and two successful businesses are going, or have gone broke.

The first grant that was brought to my attention concerned a car detailing business, the only one in the town. It was, I stress, a successful business, a husband and wife concern with four or five casual employees. Their best employee was a lady of Aboriginal descent whom they held in very high regard for her standard of work. Not only that, she was a very close personal friend of the owner of the business. She was also described to me as being an extraordinary honest person in the community, who never ever, and would not have, cheated on the Social Security system, who gave all information in respect of her earnings.

She was approached by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to set up her own car detailing business in Mount Isa in opposition to the business for which she worked. She was embarrassed. She went to her close friend who operated the business, explained the situation, and said, `What am I going to do?' This is what she told the person who owned the business: she was to be given a $15,000 loan with no repayments for two years, then repayments to commence at 2 per cent interest. If she employed two Aboriginal people each would be paid $150 a week for six months while being trained. She was to be paid $150 a week `till she gets on her feet', and the Department would buy or rent premises for her to set up her business. It is understood there would be no rent payable, at least initially. Administrative expertise would also be provided, especially in accounting and taxation.

Mr Deputy President, setting up a business in direct competition with another, even if it is a subsidised business, would not normally be a problem and perhaps could be got away with in a place such as Sydney or Melbourne. I think it is best to describe Mount Isa. It is an isolated provincial city in the far north-west of Queensland. It has a population of some 38,000 people. It is over 900 kilometres away from the nearest coastal city of Townsville. In the other direction, the nearest major city would be Darwin. To use another measure of the size of Mount Isa, it does not even yet have a McDonald's hamburger franchise in the town. That gives an idea of the sort of market that is available in such a place.

Honourable senators will know that country towns and cities have only a limited market for these types of services. The establishment of a subsidised enterprise that has no capital repayments, low or no interest, subsidised employees and free administrative work in direct opposition with another business in an area such as this has made it impossible for the original car detailing business to compete-a fact that is obvious to everyone except these people who dreamed up this lunatic grant. Mr Deputy President, I ask whether this is how the Government hopes to help Aborigines-by destroying existing small business, inciting ill will and resentment and creating racial hatred at great expense to the taxpayer.

I have no idea what the Government's response to this situation is. I wrote to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in June: I wrote to him because I did not wish to make a public issue of this matter. I thought it was best raised by way of a letter. So far he has not replied to that letter. If that were an isolated incident I would probably say, `Okay, we will pursue the Minister and see whether something can be done to stop this divisiveness that is being created in small communities', but it is not. I was made aware of another case virtually identical to this only last week. The bureaucrats who could not be bothered surveying the community needs to find an unmet demand have simply found a successful ceramic business in Mount Isa and duplicated it. What was previously a thriving business has not done any business in the last two months.

What is the reason? An Aboriginal owned ceramic business has commenced operations in direct competition with an original business-with another $25,000 Government grant. I might point out that the person who started the ceramic business in the first place had borrowed money, had some three years to go before the repayments could be made and employed one or two people part-time to help her-it was a lady-with the heavy work involved in casting ceramics. Suddenly, out of the blue, competition arrived. But it is not real competition. Premises were provided, I understand free of charge; expert assistance was provided, including the visit of instructors from the south-presumably from here; a staff of up to six assistants were paid under Commonwealth grants; and the latest techniques and equipment were provided. The results in both cases have been the same: a previously successful business has been totally ruined. The cost to the taxpayer is enormous and there is no gain to the community in terms of new services or products. The member for Mount Isa has lived there for some 25 to 30 years. He is in close contact with and has many friends within the Aboriginal community. In Mount Isa, a small town, stories spread fast and we have resentment and a significant change for the worse in the attitude of white Australians to their Aboriginal countrymen. This is what most concerns me and the member for Mount Isa.

The question, Mr Deputy President, which must be asked is: How many other cases are there like these around Australia? These are two unsolicited cases from one small, isolated community. It is apparent that this Hawke Government is determined to drive a wedge between white and black Australians through this bizarre policy of practical implementation of reverse apartheid. The Prime Minister has promised an Aboriginal treaty which will effectively create a separate Aboriginal state within Australia, and if that does not incite bitterness and division then these grants by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs almost certainly will. The great tragedy, Mr Deputy President, is that these deeds have soured relations between Aboriginal people and the rest of the Australian community to the detriment of genuinely needy Australians. Why would people wish to help Aborigines in that community if that assistance could mean the destruction of their own jobs and livelihoods?

In conclusion, I simply state that we in the Opposition believe in one Australia and this means that we are dedicated to improve the plight of Australian Aborigines. They deserve to be aided and helped-their disadvantage is our disadvantage-but we will not do it at the expense of the rest of the Australian community, as has been outlined on the two examples that I have given in respect of the subsidisation in a small community which effectively puts out of business, in a very limited market, the two businesses that were existing. I find it totally incomprehensible that this is allowed to go on. As I said earlier, it was not with any joy that I got up to speak about this. As I also mentioned part way through my speech, when the first example was drawn to my attention I did not publicise it; I wrote to the Minister. He has not had the courtesy to reply. In the interim period, while awaiting the reply, another case has popped up. Again I ask: How many are there? The effect of the policy will be the creation of dissension and disharmony in communities where there was not dissension and disharmony before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today in this matters of public interest debate to bring to the notice of the Senate the plight of a student at the Gippsland Institute of Advanced Education. The problems facing this mature age student, Margaret Gleeson, stemmed initially from the method of assessment and marking used by a lecturer and external marker in the clinical psychology unit undertaken by this student. Ms Gleeson protested first to the lecturer and then to the head of the school and because she was not satisfied with the outcome of these discussions she then appealed to the admission and qualifications committee for independent reassessment of the assignment. Her appeal was not upheld and the matter was then taken to the council of the Gippsland Institute, which then referred the matter back to the academic board for resolution. Ms Gleeson at that point was pleased to hear that the academic board would address her request for independent assessment of the controversial assignment-which, incidentally, was later published in an Australia-wide journal-and the computation of grades for assignments which she discovered had been incorrectly computed. In the event, however, the board chose not to address the matter other than to carry a motion which read:

SPEECH.PARA: The academic board supports the decision of its standing committee, the admissions and qualifications committee, in this matter.

With the avenues of appeal within the Institute closed, she then contacted a range of alternatives-the Victorian Ombudsman, the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission and the Victorian Minister for Education, the media, and a solicitor as well, in desperate attempts to have these several discrepancies addressed. The discrepancies raise these questions: Why had repeated reasonable requests for a genuinely independent assessment for an assignment been denied, given that her essay was published in the National Health Issues Journal? Why did the academic board deny her right to be heard? And, why had the scores for her two assignments been downgraded?

As of this date, Ms Gleeson believes that none of the above concerns have been satisfactorily answered and, indeed, she now believes that she has been found guilty by association for openly and actively supporting a lecturer who had been denied confirmation of tenure by the academic staff review committee at the end of his two-year probationary period. Ms Gleeson believes this has led to the politicisation of her case by the Institute.

Ms Gleeson has discovered that a memo distributed by the Assistant Director of Administration to the President of the Council implies that she is part of `an ongoing process of defamation of the Institute'. Ms Gleeson naturally deeply resents this charge. Through this whole process her continuing studies are being hampered. In the circumstances, and given the distress the whole affair is causing to Ms Gleeson, I would hope that her calls to the reasonable and responsible bodies and individuals beyond the Institute-the Victorian Ombudsman, the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission and the Victorian Minister for Education-will result in some positive and speedy action or an indication to Ms Gleeson where she might take some more positive and effective action which might conclude with some satisfactory resolution of the problem facing her and any broader issues within the Institute which may be involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to say a few words at this time about education in rural Australia and the critical problems that are being faced by rural Australians in educating their children. Some 14 years ago the Henderson Commission Inquiry into Poverty found that one-quarter of rural Australians lived in poverty, in contrast to only one-sixth of city people. According to the 1986 census, 33 of the 37 poorest electorates in Australia were in the rural areas and, therefore, only four are in the cities. In other words, on an electorate basis, 90 per cent of Australians that come into the category of the poorest of our community are rural dwellers.

SPEECH.PARA: We understand from that census that most of the families of those people are subsisting on incomes of $12,000 a year and below. The Government has admitted as much. In its 1986 economic and rural policy statement and in numerous other statements that have been put down the Government has outlined the serious problems of the rural economy. They are familiar problems to us-a higher level of farm debt, high debt servicing costs, run-down of farm capital stock, soil erosion and so forth. In other words, it seems that in the 14 years since Professor Henderson's inquiry the lot of rural Australia has worsened.

Life out in the bush is not easy but one does not expect the Government to team with the considerable natural forces working against those who do not live in the cities. In particular, one would not expect the Federal Government actually to make it more difficult for those who do not live in the cities to educate their children. The links between the rural economy and education are strong. The agricultural sector badly needs educated people who can apply their knowledge of the new agricultural products and techniques, business practices and marketing to agricultural activities.

I draw attention to the Commonwealth Government Schools Commission report of last year-a major report-entitled Schooling in Rural Australia, which is the other half of this equation. That detailed the problems of education in the rural areas most comprehensively. It outlined the problems of distance, staffing, curriculum, and poor retention rates in secondary schools-which are worse for rural Australia than for any other part of our community-and argued for strong, increased financial assistance to rural families for education purposes. It made it quite clear that from an education point of view rural Australia is the most disadvantaged sector of Australian society. It is not appropriate now to go into details of that report but I draw it to the attention of honourable senators.

Governments in the past have looked to two ways in which they might provide some assistance to rural Australia in the education of their children. The first, which is of course common to other Australia children, is the provision of Austudy. The second, which relates to only certain categories of rural children, is the provision of an allowance for isolated children.

It should be appreciated that many Australian rural families, although they live in the situation of very low income and with all the difficulties that I have already mentioned, are often asset rich. In other words, their properties can assume a value far in excess of what they seem to be able to produce in income, and their level of personal indebtedness throughout Australia is high and, unfortunately, increasing. Therefore, any step that is taken to impose a restriction on the availability to rural families of both Austudy and the isolated children's allowance on the basis of asset values in the rural Australian community should be taken particularly cautiously. Many rural families have book assets in excess of the $600,000 assets level the Government intends to impose but, as I have indicated, they have very low incomes.

I refer to the minute of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, Central Office reference 87/8183, which has been circulated to indicate to rural people the asset cut-off point that will now apply in relation to both Austudy and the isolated children's allowance-the figure of $600,000. It seems that there will be a saving of some $15m which obviously is of consequence from a national economic point of view, but I suggest respectfully that it should also be looked at in terms of the people affected. It seems that nearly 7,000 children, most of whom will come from rural Australia, will have assistance cut off under Austudy. Who will be cut off from the isolated children's allowance is yet to be determined but I suggest that it will be a very large number of Australian farming children who receive that much needed extra support at this time.

I ask the Government to give further consideration to the decision that it has made in this regard. I do not believe the Government has adequately appreciated the fact that many Australian farmers do have assets, in monetary terms, in book value terms, in excess of $600,000 but they are in real terms very poor and they are struggling to educate their children in an educational environment which has been acknowledged to be the most difficult in Australia. I think if the Government showed the sensitivity it should be showing towards families in these difficult rural circumstances it would realise that it has proceeded on a misconceived basis in relation to this new assets test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want today to make some comments with respect to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and in particular the manner in which this Government is administering the Territory. A prominent issue at the moment is self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. The coalition is of the view that the ACT needs it and needs it very badly. It cannot grow and thrive under what has become a revolving door leadership with Ministers either stepping their way up to bigger and better portfolios or finding a quiet place to rest on the way out. Last week the coalition parties indicated their strong support for self-government and the need for it to come sooner rather than later. We did, however, say that an unfair and undemocratic election system was too big a price to pay and we expressed our willingness to negotiate. On the same day that announcement was made. I appeared on Capital Seven television with the Minister for Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, in an ACT budget debate. The Minister said there that self-government was not dead-I am very pleased to hear that; I was pleased and I still am-that the Government was willing to negotiate and had amendments in mind. At the time he did say-and I believe he was correct in saying-that the Government would find it easier to draft amendments to accommodate the Australian Democrats' concerns than it would to accommodate ours. That is true. I agree that the gulf is wider between us and the Government than it is between the Democrats and the Government. Of course, a particular reason for that at this stage, Mr Deputy President, of which you may not be aware, is that the Democrats' proposed system for self-government is at times inconsistent with the plus or minus 10 provision in the fair elections Bill. So they are in a somewhat invidious position at the moment in advocating a yes vote to question two in the referendum, and yet proposing a system of self-government in the ACT that cannot at all times be consistent with that. Nonetheless, that is the Democrats' problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night, having heard nothing of the amendments that the Minister indicated he had in mind, I rang the Minister's office querying where the amendments were, whether there were going to be negotiations, and reiterating our willingness to negotiate. I was told that the Minister thought it was not worth negotiating with us, that it was more appropriate to be negotiating with the Democrats, which he had been doing and was doing at that very stage-an announcement I must say I was somewhat surprised to hear. I asked whether there were any amendments to consider and was offered an appointment with the Minister. That is as far as it has gone at this stage. I stress that, Mr Deputy President, because having outlined our willingness to negotiate, nothing having happened until last night, ringing last night to see what is going on, finding out that we have been left out-the Minister does not think it is worth bothering talking to us but I could commence negotiations with him-I was surprised to read this quote from the Minister in the Canberra Times today:
`But being realistic, and given the delicate negotiations that are being undertaken with the Liberal Party . . .

I leave it to honourable senators to make their own assessment of the Minister for making that statement. I personally regard it as inconsistent with the facts that I have outlined. Nonetheless, to return to the electoral system that is proposed for the Australian Capital Territory, the coalition regarded the electoral system basically as a bribe, a system that favours the major parties and effectively cuts out minor parties and Independents-and not a bribe that we would ever accept. It is a system in which individuals cannot vote across party lines as they can in all other elections in this country and it is an un-Australian system because we are not given a second chance. If you want to vote for an Independent, Mr Deputy President, under the Government's proposal you can put a tick by that Independent or a one in the box. Knowing your vote is being counted to elect 17 people, you can put a tick by only one box. Yet this Government has the cheek to pretend that the fair elections Bill, if passed, will ensure fair and democratic elections across the country.

Australians need only turn their mind to what is proposed in the Australian Capital Territory to see the manifest deceit in referendum question No. 2. They are asked: `Do you want a Bill that will ensure fair and democratic elections throughout Australia?'. Some people will answer yes, believing that is what they will get. The Australian Capital Territory shows that it is not what they will get, because what is proposed for the Australian Capital Territory is a vote that may have the same geographic value, but it does not have the same real value because we cannot, if we want to vote for an Independent or a small party, cast a vote for the remaining candidates and we cannot vote across party lines. Big Brother says, `You will vote for either this party or that party or you will not bother voting'. If that is one vote one value, one real value, I should think again about my logic. I am quite satisfied that it is not one vote one real value across this country which is being introduced.

In any event the Democrats, as I indicated-this is the other alternative for self-government-propose a system in which the electoral commissioner or redistribution committee would not be able on each occasion to satisfy the plus or minus 10 requirement of the fair elections Bill and comply with the Democrats' directions. In an ordinary electorate in a State the electoral commissioner can satisfy the plus or minus 10 requirement by drawing reasonably arbitrary lines on a map. What the Democrats say should happen in the Australian Capital Territory, where the map is much smaller, the flexibility is less, is that there shall be four seats; that the lines cannot go through discrete communities, they must go around; and each seat can have no less than five members. Consequently, the electoral commissioner, instead of having the capacity to draw lines in a reasonably arbitrary fashion around the edges, loses that capacity and there are times when he will be left, if the Democrats' system is introduced, with a Constitutional requirement of plus or minus 10, and a Bill that said he had to do it in a way that would not allow him to comply with the Constitution.

There has been a deathly silence from the Democrats about this mistake, which they admit. They started admitting by saying it was a small anomaly that could be corrected: it has not yet been corrected. What I want to put on record by outlining the events with respect to self-government is that I hope that the new Minister, because I have just about given up on the existing one, has a new and refreshing attitude to negotiating with the coalition, that he does not say one thing and do another. We are keen to negotiate to get self-government for the Australian Capital Territory, we believe that self-government is not only inevitable but, because of the lousy administration by this Government, it is an imperative.

I want to turn to another matter in the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Acting Deputy President, and that is the development of section 19. Before I do that I might say one more thing with respect to self-government, and it is this: I believe there is something of a covert agenda. Let me put it this way: Canberra is a government town. It has a very high proportion of public servants. All other legislatures that govern themselves, obviously, spell out the opportunities vis-a-vis public servants. All of them, except New South Wales and Tasmania, say that a public servant of the Commonwealth, another State or their State cannot hold office. However, in New South Wales and Tasmania one can be a Commonwealth public servant or the public servant of another State-but not a public servant of that particular State-and hold office. The bottom line is that every other legislature is not silent on the opportunities for public servants and thus far the Minister's drafting instructions are.

One might think this is somewhat inconsequential because what in effect happens in the States is that arrangements are made for public servants who want to stand, to have a go, to stand down when the writs are issued and, if they do not win the election, they get the job back; if they win they resign. One might say, `Well, what does it matter?' The reason it matters is that they can afford to resign from the Public Service, they can have a real opportunity to participate in government, only if there is a decent salary, roughly a full time salary. Otherwise, they cannot afford it. In the old advisory assembly in the ACT, Mr Acting Deputy President, what a public servant was permitted to do was not collect an assembly salary and, therefore, not put himself in conflict. But we are now talking about real self-government, real legislative powers, and the Australian Capital Territory will not be able to be silent on this issue. The question needs to be addressed.

That leads me to the covert agenda. Why has this not been addressed? The Minister says in his public statements that he is looking for `an assembly of 17', and then he says, `with four full-time Ministers'. The impli- cation, the impression that has been given very widely through the Australian Capital Territory, is that this will predominantly be a part-time assembly. That is the impression that has been given. But I believe the Government intends the full assembly to be full-time. I believe it intends recommending to the Remuneration Tribunal that if self-government proceeds the salaries should be full-time. I think it is keeping that to itself and I think that is a very bad thing. It is most unfortunate that the Government seeks in this matter to be ambiguous and misleading. Apart from ambiguity and misleading statements not being acceptable from a government in any event, they are particularly unacceptable in this respect. I come back to where I started in this matter: Canberra is basically a government town and so to be ambiguous and misleading as to the opportunities of public servants to participate in self-government is even worse in the Australian Capital Territory. It does the Government no credit to behave in this fashion.

Let me quickly turn to the Civic Square redevelopment, section 19, an idea that was conceived of about 12 months ago. About one month ago we received draft legislation-11 months in the making. I do not complain about that. I am not critical about the time because it is very important to get the legislation right. I quite agree with that. What I am critical about is Minister Punch seeking approval of his idea before he produces the legislation, before he gets the details sorted out. One does not see Dawkins running around in tears because everybody has not received his idea of a graduate tax with acclamation. He is a true believer. He is prepared to fight for what he believes in. He does not just wait until everyone else agrees before he fronts up to the barrier. We do not see the Treasurer (Mr Keating) refusing to put out a Budget unless the Opposition agrees. It is a ridiculous notion. No other Minister seeks a reply before details are available. No other Minister, in fact, expects a reply on legislation before he puts it up for debate-not one. As I said, we do not see Dawkins complaining. He knows he has to wait until he puts his legislation up. Similarly, we do not see Keating afraid to put up the Budget because the other side has not agreed yet.

The ACT, some would say, needs a new theatre and refurbished library. There may be some debate about that. In any event, there are promised developments and benefits to the ACT from the section 19 project proceeding. All we are saying to the Minister is that if he can show how he can guarantee they will be delivered, we will consider the legislation early before he puts it on for debate. What he has to show is that section 19 will not end up just the same as the convention centre project, on which the people of the ACT were told, `For all this office space you will get a convention centre'. They got the office space quickly and they still have not got the convention centre. That is all that the Minister is required to do. If he does that we will give him an answer before he is prepared to take the step of putting the legislation on for debate. I do not think that is unreasonable. I certainly hope that the new Minister takes a much more reasonable, sensible and pragmatic approach to government in the ACT.
Sitting suspended from 1.27 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Foreign Minister designate and the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the outrage and concern he expressed in the Senate last week about the damage to Australia's standing in Asia which, he suggested, would flow from the debate in this country about immigration policy. Does he recall saying that Australia's image had been damaged and that reports reaching the region were likely to have serious adverse consequences for Australia's trading access and commercial opportunities? Noting his statement that he was appalled at what had happened in recent weeks, I ask the Minister whether he is similarly appalled at the derogatory and racist generalisations of his former colleague, Mr Bill Hayden, in describing Indonesians as `erratic, hostile people to deal with' and in describing the Japanese approach to the Association of South East Asian Nations as their `hypocritical, self-effacing way' among many other inflammatory statements. Noting Senator Gareth Evans's claim that diplomatic posts in the region had been reporting concerns about the immigration debate, can the Minister tell the Senate whether reports are being received from our Asian-Pacific representatives about these comments by the man who is shortly to become Australia's Head of State and who therefore will have to officially represent Australia in dealings with our Pacific neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am concerned about the damage that may flow from the leaking of documents involving, as they do, private expressions of opinion made in a particular context at particular times in the past. What appals me far more, however, is two things: First of all, the deliberate and public statements that have been made by a variety of spokesmen on the Opposition side, not in private, not in the context of particular events at particular times, but deliberate policy positions of a kind which can serve no other purpose than to inflame domestic prejudice and inflame a very adverse reaction overseas.
—Humbug!

—To talk in the terms that Senator Stone did, to talk in the terms that Mr Sinclair did and to talk in the terms that Mr Howard did about the need to reduce the flow of Asian immigrants to this country, is to talk in terms which are deliberately and disgracefully offensive. To talk in terms which are bound by their very deliberate and public nature, is bound to excite a far more continuing degree of concern, anxiety and hostility towards this country than views expressed in private and in particular contexts by people who have no intention whatsoever of making those views public. I said that there was a second thing about this whole affair that appalled me and it is the utter failure of any Opposition spokesman and in particular Mr Spender, who to our lasting disbenefit is back in the country and pontificating again on these subjects, to express any degrees of distaste or any degree of concern about the leaking and the publication of this particular material.

ANSWER.PARA: We have not heard an expression from anyone on the other side about the damage that may flow, not from the content of these remarks but from their illegal distribution, publication and leaking. It is that which does the damage, it is that which demonstrates the utter absence of any kind of commitment to basic principles on the other side. To condone or in fact to encourage such disclosures, which is the kind of language that we have been hearing from the other side in recent days, is of course to endanger the capacity of this Government or of any other government to pursue Australia's foreign relations in the national interest.

The Government, by contrast, regards the leaking of any document of this kind as being very serious indeed. We do not accept the Spender dispensation that it is simply a very great pity that documents are leaked but that no responsibility attaches to those who do it. To put the issue in those terms in the way that it has been put by the Opposition demonstrates an utter and complete failure to have regard to the real nature of the issues involved in this case and the real nature of Australia's interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will desist from commenting on the fact that the issue is not the leaking of the document but the comments on nationals of countries in our neighbourhood and the way this reflects the official Labor Government's view of them. I will ignore the McCarthyist portrayal that the Minister has put forward. I want to know whether the Minister is embarrassed by those statements which are now on the public record and how he is, as a future Foreign Minister, this month and next month going to deal with the governments of Papua New Guinea and Indonesia on his official visit?

—I will deal with them with a lot more charm and competence than the honourable senator would be able to manage, I can tell him. What I do say, as I said yesterday morning, is that other countries can be completely assured that Australia's foreign policy and Australia's attitude to its neighbours are exactly as has been articulated in definitive public statements by the Government. I refer again, as I did yesterday, to our complete commitment to the development of friendly and productive relations with all the countries of our region and our commitment to an independent foreign policy based on Australia's national interest. It is very well understood that that is the nature of our position and the nature of our true beliefs about our neighbours. I am sure that I will have no difficulty whatsoever in communicating that to our neighbours.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Bearing in mind the recent revelations of widespread and institutionalised corruption in Queensland, can the Minister inform the Senate how the passage of the referendum on fair and democratic elections on Saturday will provide more accountable government throughout Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that if there is one political environment in which a government can grow complacent and corrupt itself or at least turn a blind eye to corruption in its officers-including those who have the special responsibility of law enforcement-it is when it has an arrogant assumption that, come what may, the general population of the State concerned can be ignored because of electoral arrangements which favour the party in power. There is no doubt that in Queensland one has had a situation grow up, over the last several decades, where a government has been able to ignore completely the wishes of the large mass of the people of the State concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, the fact is, as we know, that Mr Innes, the parliamentary Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland, has pleaded with his Federal colleagues to support the second question to be put to the people next Saturday, in order that there indeed be a form of fair and democratic elections instituted in Queensland for the election of that State's Legislative Assembly. It is surprising really in that we know or suspect that many members on the Opposition side in this chamber and in the House of Representatives, when it comes to the privacy of the ballot box, will be voting yes in relation to that particular question. In doing so, they would be concurring in the plea of Mr Innes, the Leader of the parliamentary Liberal Party in Queensland who, in a press release dated 22 June, has pointed out:

. . . the referendum on fair electoral boundaries to be held in September would give Queenslanders an opportunity to smash the gerrymander and ensure future governments were elected that represented all voters.
He did that in the context of pointing out:
Queensland's gerrymander had resulted in almost 75 per cent of the state's population having only one voice in Cabinet . . .
Brisbane, with 50 per cent of the state's population, had only one junior minister . . .
No Cabinet ministers represented . . . major provincial cities of Ipswich, Townsville, Toowoomba, Rockhampton, Cairns, Bundaberg, Mackay, Gladstone, Maryborough, and Mount Isa.

That is the sort of situation which has evolved in Queensland, and which allowed Mr Russ Hinze to give the game away only a few days ago when he went to the heart of the matter and said that the boundaries are rigged in Queensland and all that one needed was to get a National Party tag in some of the smaller, more remote electorates and one was in, I think he said, forever and a day. That has allowed the institutionalised corruption which is being revealed day by day in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct to prosper because the Queensland Government has felt no need to be accountable to the whole electorate.

It is no good trying to hide behind States rights tags in relation to question No. 2. Mr Innes has already blown that argument out of the water, as have some of the more courageous Liberal Party members of the House of Representatives who have refused to support their Party's position on this question. The passage of the referendum to ensure that when Australians vote for members of parliament they have their vote valued in the same way as every other person voting in that election will appeal to the sense of fairness in the Australian community in general. It is interesting that in a small survey taken of 3,000 year 11 and year 12 students in Tasmania recently, those students supported question No. 2. They gave it an affirmative vote. That shows that certainly in Tasmania there will be plenty of support for this proposition, as there will be across the whole of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the calm and rational approach of the Papua New Guinea Government earlier this year when elements of the Indonesian army crossed into the west Sepik area of PNG in pursuit of alleged OPM forces, and to the reported six or seven other Indonesian military crossings this year. Does that not indicate a greater maturity in PNG politics than Mr Hayden gave it credit for when, in not dissimilar circumstances, he said in 1984-we now learn-when the current PNG Prime Minister was the Foreign Minister:

QUESTION.PARA: My worry is that the Papua New Guineans are likely to be faced down in their rather clumsy bluff, and that given their limited maturity and experience in such matters, might proceed with more bluster and bluff, getting deeper and deeper into a quagmire of confusion and incompetence.
I ask: Does not the Government realise that a more respectful, less patronising attitude towards PNG is in Australia's national interest?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing patronising, disrespectful or in any other way misconceived about Australia's attitude, public and private, as both held and communicated to the Papua New Guinea Government. Remarks alleged to have been made by Mr Hayden at an earlier time have to be seen in the context of the particular time, situation and occurrence in respect of which they were made, and also against the background of appreciating that they were not in any way intended for a wider audience. Under those circumstances the sort of indignation that Senator Hill is demonstrating on this occasion is synthetic in the extreme and unworthy of someone of his intelligence and integrity.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen copies of a letter and pamphlet distributed in the name of the Queensland Premier, Mr Ahern, and paid for by the Queensland Government as part of the Queensland National Party's campaign against the referendum question for fair and democratic elections? Will the Minister ask the Treasurer to reduce Queensland's financial assistance grants by an amount equal to the cost of this print campaign, as he has done in respect of the Queensland Government's television campaign against the referendum question on fair and democratic elections? Can the Minister advise how such a political campaign should be funded?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the pamphlet. Indeed, I have a copy here. It is coloured and is on good quality paper. I do not know what it cost, but it must have cost Queensland taxpayers a packet. Indirectly, it cost Commonwealth taxpayers a packet because Queensland gets so much of its revenue from the Commonwealth Government. I also have a copy of the letter from Mr Ahern which is signed by him but is not authorised and, therefore, is probably in breach of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It obviously would have involved quite a lot of additional expenditure to have that letter posted out, in envelopes, postage and the time to prepare it. The pamphlet would obviously involve some distribution costs as well. That expenditure is additional to the $750,000 or $800,000 which the Queensland Minister for Finance has admitted has been spent on the television campaign. Every time Queenslanders see one of those Queensland Government financed pieces of propaganda urging a no vote in the referendum, that is $2,000 that is not going to be spent on roads, hospitals, bridges or education in Queensland. It is $2,000 taken away from those things every time Queenslanders see that bit of political propaganda, funded by taxpayers' money and put to air by the Queensland National Party Government in order to protect and preserve, it hopes, the corrupt electoral system which has produced the sort of political and legal outcome which is a matter of almost daily scandal at the Fitzgerald Royal Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. Queensland is a State governed by a corrupt police force, the League of Rights and a few members of the white shoe brigade, which has been festering for 31 years leading to the sort of corrupt administration that has finally been exposed in the Fitzgerald Royal Commission and which is finally being flushed out.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked how political campaigns should be financed and run. I have an example: a full page advertisement from yesterday's Courier-Mail. It is a bit hard to recognise the picture but it is actually a reproduction of Russ Hinze's face-or is supposed to be. It is a pretty rough reproduction, but the words certainly are Russ Hinze's. The advertisement says:

I've carried the National Party, unlike some of the seats in Queensland that are rigged . . . to the extent that the boundaries . . . all you have to do is get the National Party tag and you can win it for ever and a day.
That was broadcast on Australian Broadcasting Corporation news on 22 August. That, of course, is an Australian Labor Party advertisement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone is laughing at this answer. He does not think it is serious. He is totally cynical.

—He is laughing, is he? I do not suppose that he is the author of this advertisement? But that is proper political advertising. It is authorised by Wayne Swan of the Australian Labor Party and it is paid for by Labor Party funds, not by taxpayers' funds.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I refer the Minister to that part of my question which asked whether he would ask the Treasurer to reduce Queensland's financial assistance grants by an amount equal to the cost of this print campaign, as he has done in respect of the Queensland Government's television campaign against the referendum on fair and democratic elections.

—I must apologise to Senator Colston for having failed to answer that part of the question. I will of course ask the Treasurer to examine this question of whether Queensland should have a further fine for squandering another few hundred thousand dollars, or a few million or whatever it is, of taxpayers' money by quite improperly distributing this pamphlet.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of the United Kingdom Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, the Rt Hon. Lord Young of Graffam. On behalf of all senators I extend to him a warm welcome to Australia and to Canberra in particular. I trust that he enjoys his visit.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware that in spite of the nine-year tenure provided to service station operators by the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchising Act, oil companies are presently forcing lessees to forgo the 12-month balance of their present tenure as the price of issue of new leases? Does the Minister agree that this action by the oil companies is unfair and inconsistent with the spirit of the Act? If so, has he put this view to the oil companies? Does the Minister agree that the processes being engaged in by the oil companies are against the interests of service station operators, their employees and their families? If he does, what action does he intend to take on the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of the allegations to this effect contained in the honourable senator's question. However, it has always been accepted that oil companies should be under no further obligation to those dealers whose franchise agreements expire after the full nine-year term granted under the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act. To remove business uncertainty for selected dealers, I understand that certain companies are offering new agreements before the expiry of the old ones with a pro rata adjustment to the new franchise fees. Such offers, or the payment of any franchise fees involved, are not in themselves contrary to the spirit of the legislation. I think Senator Macklin will be aware that the Trade Practices Commission is due to complete its study into petrol pricing next month. We will be watching the outcome of this study with interest, as pricing and the issues raised are no doubt interrelated.

ANSWER.PARA: However, representations have been made to the Government, consistent with the allegations in Senator Macklin's question, by dealers who consider some of the terms being offered by certain oil companies in their new franchise agreements to be onerous and contrary to both the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act and the Trade Practices Act and are considering legal challenges to their validity.

The Government's parliamentary legal and administrative committee is monitoring this situation. I consider, and I am sure that Senator Macklin would agree, that such issues should essentially be a matter for commercial judgment and negotiation between the parties involved. However, if as a result of investigation there is clear evidence that a franchise agreement is unfair or unconscionable, or bullying tactics are being applied by oil companies, I certainly will be prepared to intervene on the dealers' behalf and seek explanation from the oil companies concerned regarding their intentions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Justice seen claims by the Victorian Federal member of parliament, Mr David Hawker, in the Naracoorte Herald of South Australia that the Commonwealth Government is `conning local councils' on referendum question No. 3? What is the Minister's response to this claim?
—It is a thinking man's newspaper.

—It is indeed. Is it the case that Mr Jeff Kennett, the Liberal Leader in Victoria, is supporting the referendum to recognise local government in the Constitution, contrary to the position of Mr Hawker, the Federal Liberal Party and Mr Howard? Is the Government united on the referenda, in contrast to the position of the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the pleasure of reading yesterday's copy of the Naracoorte Herald, or whatever it is, but I must say that what is attributed to Mr Hawker is precisely in line with the misinformation and the misleading scaremongering that has occurred in relation to all the referendum questions as far as many of the Opposition members are concerned, with a few honourable exceptions. In relation to question No. 3, dealing with the recognition of the existence of local government as an important third sphere of our good, working democracy in Australia, the distortion of a very simple proposal has been profound. The remarks attributed to Mr Hawker are, as I say, in line with the misinformation campaign which has been put around, much to the dismay of those who, over decades, have sought to give to this third sphere of government, close to the people, its rightful place in the Australian Constitution, the basic document of our democracy.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Maguire hinted at in his question, it is by no means the case that the Opposition is united in this matter. Some of its members have been unable to go along with the campaign of misinformation. I have in my notes a letter circulated by Mr Ian Wilson, the Federal member for Sturt, an Adelaide electorate, who quite properly, in circulating his views to the members of his electorate, advocated a Yes vote on this question. A tribute is due to Mr Wilson for so doing.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently, honourable senators opposite find it distasteful that one of their colleagues should break ranks in this way. But Mr Wilson is not alone amongst members of the Liberal Party in advocating a Yes vote. What has captured the imagination of many Australians is the fact that the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson, has gone on the record time and time again advocating a Yes vote. When somebody such as Sallyanne Atkinson advocates a Yes vote around Australia there is a very good chance that this question will be carried.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, it will not be carried if the misinformation campaign put around by the Opposition is allowed to go unchallenged. That is why the Australian Local Government Association, in a letter written by its director to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, on 25 August, has spoken about Mr Reith's characterisation of the local government question as containing blatant lies which would do an enormous amount of damage to the Liberal Party's credibility with local government, both in the short and the long term. When the leading spokesman for the Opposition during this referendum campaign tells blatant lies about this proposal I am sure that, because they are blatant, they will be seen through and the general public will endorse the proposal.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RELATIONS WITH SOUTH EAST ASIA AND THE PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade designate and Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government going to do about the fact that no government in South East Asia and the Pacific will ever again believe the publicly expressed opinion of the Hawke Government towards the countries of the region now that they know the derogatory opinions held by the former Foreign Minister and put in writing by him to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the premise on which the question was founded. As the Prime Minister said yesterday, there is nothing in the Government's clear policy of commitment to close relations with the countries of our region which is qualified in any way by the publication of alleged private comments by the former Foreign Minister. This Government has focused policy on our region, as no previous government ever did, in terms of attention, resources and ministerial interest. Those actions will speak louder than any privately communicated words made in the context of a particular situation, a particular time and a particular place.

ANSWER.PARA: I have made it clear, and will make it clear in the future-as the Prime Minister already has and other spokesmen have-that the countries of our region can be completely assured that Australia's foreign policy remains committed to exactly the same objectives as have been applied by this Government since 1983.

It has been articulated on innumerable occasions in the definitive statements made by the Prime Minister and senior Ministers. It is these statements which define the Government's policy. It is these statements developed by Ministers and officials which weigh up the various factors which bear upon our national interest.

In the formulation, consideration and development of foreign policy it is obviously proper for opinions to be expressed privately. That happens in every county of the world, every country of the region, and there will undoubtedly be some understanding of that. It is the people involved in the public disclosure of that material, the people who gave aid, comfort, nourishment and support, of the kind that we have seen from the Opposition benches, for sordid and squalid political reasons in the last couple of days who put at risk Australia's foreign relations and the national interest. I repeat that to in any way condone or encourage that kind of behaviour, those kinds of disclosures, is to endanger the capacity of this Government or of any other government to pursue the national interest internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It follows the categorisation of advice from the former Foreign Minister to his Department as private comments. I ask the Minister: Is he suggesting that those comments were made otherwise than in the former Minister's ministerial capacity to his Department? I ask: Has he or the Government formally repudiated all of the views which have been so expressed? If the Government has done that, how are our Asian neighbours supposed to know that any such public repudiation is not simply overlying the same private stereotyping that is obvious from these remarks?
—I do not want to add to my previous answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General whether he has had occasion to note the letter in this morning's Age from the Secretary of the Buddhist Council of Victoria, headed `Discrimination on religious grounds is widespread here'. While I do not intend to read all of it, the letter contains the following passages:

QUESTION.PARA: Churchmen urging us to vote No have assured us that the existing legal freedom of religion is quite adequate.

After talking with Buddhist and Islamic leaders in many cities, a clear picture emerges. Religious discrimination is widespread throughout Australia and the victims of it have almost no legal opportunity to counteract it.
The letter then goes on to talk about the difficulties that South East Asian refugees have. The last sentence says:
For Moslems the situation is worse.
Has the Minister noted the letter and, if so, is there anything that this Government or the people of Australia can do about that situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately in the rush of ministerial duties this morning I have read neither the Age nor the Naracoorte Herald, so I have not had an opportunity to read the letter from the Secretary of the Buddhist Council of Victoria. Nevertheless, the sentiments he there expresses and the genuine apprehension he has about the place of the adherents of minority religious beliefs in Australia is something we ought to take account of. In particular, when we have the responsibility, and indeed the privilege, of dealing with the fundamental democratic document, the Constitution, which Australians will be asked to amend on 3 September, next Saturday, we ought to take the opportunity to ensure that, although at the moment we are living in a relatively calm and tolerant time in our Australian society, in the next decade and into the next century, and thereby into the next millennium, we have a fundamental political structure guaranteed in our Constitution which ensures that the adherents of minority religions have the same practical effective opportunity to exercise their religious beliefs freely as do those who now find themselves in a majority in that regard. I also refer to those who do not adhere to any religious belief.

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court of Australia has consistently said in relation to the present provision in the Constitution that that is its precise role in our society. That is why it has been so important, certainly as a guarantee against the use of Commonwealth parliamentary power to enforce any particular point of view, to impose any political or religious observance, or to interfere with the free practice of religion by any group in Australia.

We know that the State parliaments, nevertheless, are not bound to observe the inherent human dignity of Australians who come within State jurisdictions in this regard. We know that the common law is an inadequate protection against State parliaments and governments who would interfere with this freedom, perhaps not this week, perhaps not this year, though what the Secretary of the Buddhist Council of Victoria points to is certain activity which may have the colouring of discrimination against those minority religions. The present Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason, in an address to a lawyers conference recently said that the common law is not the invincible safeguard of our rights that it was once thought to be. If we can entrench this important right in our Constitution against State and Territory parliaments and governments, as it is at the moment against the Commonwealth Parliament, we will be doing much to set a framework within which Australia can, I hope, retain its reputation as a tolerant society.

When one hears the warning bells that have been sounded over the last few weeks in relation to the racist question, the question of minority ethnic groups, one cannot have the same confidence one may have had several months ago about the place of minority groups in our society. When added to an ethnic or racial minority status is adherence to a religion which is unfamiliar to the great majority of Australians, then one has the possibility of discrimination being practised. In that situation, if we can next Saturday as an Australian nation guarantee to all persons in Australia that their freedom to practice their religion will not be interfered with by governments and parliaments, now or in the future, we will be doing a great service to this nation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Will the Minister apologise for his scandalous personal attack on me at the last Senate sittings, when he described me as, amongst other things, despicable, contemptible, inaccurate, irresponsible, near hysterical, erroneous, reckless, cruel and even ghoulish, because I said radar was desperately needed at Coolangatta Airport, scene of a fatal mid-air collision in May of this year? The Minister denied that there was any need for radar or that there were any safety problems at all at Coolangatta. Subsequently, and I produce newspaper cuttings to prove it, the nation's air pilots and air traffic controllers threatened Australia-wide industrial action unless radar was installed at Coolangatta as soon as humanly possible.

QUESTION.PARA: There have been several close shaves at Coolangatta since the last Senate sittings, including an incident which made the front page of the Gold Coast Bulletin of 24 August 1988. Will the Minister now admit he was wrong and retract the comments he made about me? I seek leave to table the bundle of press clippings about near misses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The allegations that generated that invective were, of course, that I had been somehow personally responsible for causing not only the tragic crash that occurred over Coolangatta but also a series of crashes that were said to be imminent as a result of my own neglect. That, combined with a series of other extravagant allegations about my failure to visit at the particular time and place and in the circumstances that Senator Sheil thought were appropriate, amply justified the response and the very large bucket that I endeavoured to tip over him on that occasion obviously with some degree of success because the wounds are still hurting.

ANSWER.PARA: I did not for a moment deny that the question of a radar system for Coolangatta was something that properly should command the urgent attention of the Government and the new Civil Aviation Authority. That has happened and it has been announced, as Senator Sheil said, that there will been an accelerated program for the supply and installation of both primary and secondary radar systems.

What I was concerned to respond to was the suggestion that the absence of radar was itself some kind of direct and immediate cause of the crash that occurred. What was involved in the circumstances of that crash was a visual observation arrangement for circuit training for the aircraft in question, as I recall, which procedures are followed at every comparable airport in the country. It was a tragedy that that accident occurred but it was not something that could be attributed in any direct or immediate way to the absence of radar and certainly not to my personal neglect. So if Senator Sheil does not like that, he can lump it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the difficulty being experienced by Mrs Sheila Suttner in obtaining a South African visa which she requires urgently on compassionate grounds? Mrs Suttner's need to visit South Africa is to be close to her son Raymond, still in gaol after two years under emergency powers, and to be with her daughter Sally, both of whom are suffering from stress induced ill health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that Raymond Suttner, a South African law lecturer, has been detained without charge or trial by Senator Sheil's friends in South Africa since the state of emergency proclamation in mid-1986. As the sole white political detainee, he has effectively been segregated in solitary confinement for most of his two-year imprisonment. Not surprisingly, his health has markedly declined, particularly in recent months. The Australian Government has taken and continues to take a close interest in Suttner's case, not least because his mother is an Australian citizen. Due to Raymond Suttner's deteriorating medical condition, Mrs Suttner recently made a visa application to the South African Embassy in order to visit him in South Africa. Her daughter is also reportedly to be suffering from a stress-related illness.

ANSWER.PARA: The latest advice to Mrs Suttner from the South African Embassy is that visa issue could take up to three months. The Australian Government recognises and respects that visa issue is a matter relating to the sovereignty of governments but, clearly, there are overriding humanitarian considerations that are quite specific to this case. Let me simply express the hope that South African authorities will view Mrs Suttner's visa application in a favourable light.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RELATIONS WITH SOUTH EAST ASIA AND PACIFIC

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Foreign Minister designate, representing the Minister with caretaker responsibilities for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns his explanations about remarks apparently made by Mr Hayden when that person was Foreign Minister. The Minister has made some play in his responses about particular words being used at particular times in a particular place. I ask the Minister whether he is suggesting that there was ever a time when such words would have been acceptable or appropriate comments by a Foreign Minister. Will he now make it clear to the Parliament and, through the Parliament, to our neighbours, that the words did not ever represent the views of the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already said, all I have been suggesting is that in the formulation and consideration of the development of foreign policy it is quite proper for opinions to be expressed privately, and to be unable to have the fullest and frankest exchanges between Ministers and officials would circumscribe policy-making in an unacceptable way. If the statements that are alleged to have been made by Mr Hayden were generalised expressions of a prevailing ministerial or government view about the countries in question, obviously I would wish to say that those views are not shared in that way by this particular Government and I have indicated already that we have put innumerable statements on the public record articulating our view of those countries and our relationships with those countries.

ANSWER.PARA: The point is that things are said and done in the heat of the moment, particularly in what are believed to be private exchanges, which one would be most unhappy to see in the public domain; that happens in all our private relationships, as I imagine some of the more sensitive members of the Opposition, like Senator Baume, would well appreciate. What hurts on these occasions and what leads the Government to make the kind of response it has, with police investigations and High Court of Australia injunctions and so on, is not so much the fact of opinions like this being expressed at particular times in particular places and in particular contexts. What hurts is the leaks, the disclosures and the publicity attached to them, and it is that which ought to be attracting the condemnation of the Opposition, rather than the flow of crocodile tears we are seeing from people who, by their deliberate public statements in recent weeks, have done more deliberately to affect the course of Australia's relationships with other countries than anything that Mr Hayden may have done in the course of his illustrious career.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of a report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 30 August 1988 entitled `Triumphant return of disabled ath- letes', showing athletes proudly displaying gold medals-bronze and silver, for that matter-won at the Westfield Bicentennial Games for athletes with disabilities? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's involvement in these games and, further, outline the extent of government commitment to providing equitable access to sport and recreation opportunities for people with disabilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked about the Westfield challenge which took place a few weeks ago for people with dis- abilities. In fact, I think this is the first time for some years that a question has been asked in the Senate about help for people with disabilities and probably that is overdue. Senator Crowley has had a long term interest and I congratulate her for that. The first Westfield challenge was held in 1985, when the Government made a grant of $150,000, as a seeding grant, for the first games.
—If you can talk for 15 minutes it will help Gareth.

—Senator Hill may have no interest at all in sport for the disabled, but I do, honourable senators on this side of the chamber do, and I will take some time to answer the question. Three hundred and seventy athletes took part in those games in the following sports: swimming, track and field, weight lifting, power lifting, archery and table tennis. The Westfield challenge, which was held in Sydney over three days just a few weeks ago, brought together 400 athletes from six disability groups and I thought it was a tremendous example of what State and Commonwealth cooperation can do with the private sector in an area of great need. From that beginning in 1985 we have seen tremendous growth in the last three years.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the benefits that it can bring. Obviously, it can heighten the awareness of us all to the athletic potential of people with disabilities, and that is important. Obviously, it can offer encouragement to more disabled people to participate and that, I would suggest, is extremely important. Lastly, it is the provision of a much needed opportunity for competition at a higher level for those athletes who seek to take part. Obviously, that is in line with general government policy, but in view of the particular disabilities that these people suffer, I think it is especially important. All those who took part in the games themselves and those who helped to organise the challenge deserve our congratulations.

I hope that we shall provide equality of access in sport over the next few years. In that area this Government has gone much further than those opposite ever did when they were in government. In fact, in the last year of the Liberal-National Party Government less than $200,000 was spent on sport for the disabled. This year, our grant of $900,000 is way up on our first grant of $456,000, and has more than doubled what the previous Government ever attempted-and that is only in one area of disabled sport. The money that we give to those organisations and what we do in the coaching area and a whole range of other areas represents a figure getting up towards $2m. That is a Hawke Labor Government initiative. No-one on the other side of the Senate ever thought about doing that, let alone actually doing it. All I can say is that the Government is proud of its record in that respect. It is delighted that the Westfield challenge has been such a success and we shall continue to fund those sorts of endeavours.
