—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen an article which appeared under the name of Senator John Stone in this morning's Australian? Does the article contain endorsement of the Government's fiscal strategy and encapsulate the argument for not providing generous cuts in personal income tax this year? What will be the difference in the Government's fiscal position next year to enable it to provide significant tax cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see an article in the Australian published under Senator Stone's name. Given the Daily Mail experience, where an article published under Senator Stone's name was in fact ghosted by some Murdoch hack, I suppose we cannot be sure that this article was actually written by Senator Stone. However, in this case I think that it was written by Senator Stone. I will not quote too extensively from the article but he refers, among other things, to an interview which Laurie Oakes had with the Prime Minister on the Sunday program of 20 August. The article quotes a couple of paragraphs from the Prime Minister in which he spells out the reasons why the Government had made the judgment that it would not be responsible to give major tax cuts in this financial year. Senator Stone then states in the article:

ANSWER.PARA: Now I don't always praise Mr Hawke's economic analysis but this time he is spot on.
Senator Stone says `this time he is spot on'. In doing that he flatly repudiates what the Leader of the Opposition has been mouthing, that is, that we must have tax cuts now-tax cuts right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone's will usually prevails.

—Yes; I have noticed that indubitably Senator Stone's will prevails in the end. I am not sure whether that is a good thing or a bad thing. As well, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said on 18 August:

ANSWER.PARA: The need for tax cuts in sheer economic terms for people to be able to cope is very real and ought to be addressed in the Budget next week.
So Senator Stone repudiates both the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and he is quite correct to do so. On 17 August the Deputy Leader of the Opposition also said:

I can give an undertaking, as you will see when we release our tax policy, to give significant tax cuts, and I can use a figure to get it into context. If you were seeking to get back to household income . . .

He then went on to say that there had to be a tax cut of $56 a week for people on average weekly earnings. Since only average weekly earnings have been cited, it is not possible to calculate with any precision the total cost of such a tax cut. However, on the assumption of $56 a week for people on average weekly earnings and the same proportion for people on other incomes, My hunch-and I have not calculated this-is that the cost of such tax cuts would be something in excess of $12 billion. That is the revenue that would be forgone to provide tax cuts of that size. Mr Peacock is running around saying that there should be tax cuts of this magnitude right now, but Senator Stone has repudiated that. Of course, Senator Stone is absolutely right in repudiating him. As Mr Peacock said, he-that is, Mr Peacock-is not an accountant and he does not believe in bringing an accountant's approach to bear on the subject of public expenditure. As I said the other day, who needs an accountant when a bottle of snake oil will do? That is the attitude displayed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. This is the sort of nonsense that is pouring out of the mouth of the Leaders of the Opposition, and it continues a tradition which began some years ago. For example, in April 1987 Mr Howard said:
We have a policy on tax, the only thing that's missing is the numbers.

That is the Andrew Peacock approach to expenditure applied to taxation: you have a tax policy but you do not know what the numbers are. Again, who needs to be able to count when a bit of snake oil will do? To be completely fair to Senator Stone's article, I should mention that he was critical of the Government on certain grounds. He argued that, while the Government was absolutely correct to do what it has done in the recent Budget-repudiating both the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in the process-it would not be responsible to give significant tax cuts in the next financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of expenditure cuts.

—Okay, in the absence of expenditure cuts. I look forward, but I do not intend to hold my breath while doing so, to receiving a detailed list from Senator Stone or from Mr Peacock of the expenditure cuts that they propose should be made in the next Budget. Next year there will be two very significant changes. Firstly, there will be further real declines in public expenditure and about another full percentage point decline in public expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP). Next year on present expectations public expenditure will fall to around 24.5 per cent of GDP, which is down to very close to the level of the late 1960s and, of course, it is massively below the level of public expenditure in any of the seven years of the Fraser-Howard reign. The notional surplus which will be available to fund tax cuts-

—On a point of order, Mr President: Ministers give answers of unlimited length during Question Time, and that is obvious, but the Minister for Finance seems to be going for a record. I would ask you to call him to order to enable further questions to be asked.
—It is a very long answer and I would ask the Minister for Finance to conclude.

—I apologise, Mr President. I will round off very quickly. There are two points: firstly, the notional surplus which will be available next financial year to fund tax cuts will be very much larger than this year's surplus; and, secondly, it is explicit in the national wage case handed down by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission case last month that tax cuts will be an important determinant-if not the most important-of wage case decisions next year and therefore of wages outcomes.

—This will probably be the last occasion on which I will be able to ask a question of the Minister for Transport and Communications in his current capacity. After eight years of establishment and with a sixth Minister coming up, and after constant representations having been made, can the Minister issue the licence for the coastal community FM radio station at Wynyard in Tasmania before he vacates this portfolio and before the operators have to start all over again? Is there any facet of their operation that remains unfulfilled? Are there any problems with the operators or with the Department that are holding up the issue of the licence, which is so eagerly awaited by many thousands of people in north-western Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would love to go out in a blaze of glory in Senator Archer's estimation, but I am afraid that the issue is a little bit more complicated than that, as I hope I made clear in a letter that I sent him just a couple of days ago. I am aware that a Wynyard based group has an active interest, and has had one for a long time, in establishing a public radio service for north-western Tasmania. This group, known for many years as Christian FM Broadcasters, proposed to provide a special interest Christian radio service. However, the public radio planning guidelines state that the first public licence in a regional area shall not be for a special interest group but will be a community licence and that a second public licence, which shall not normally be invited for at least two years after the first community licence, may be a special interest licence or, alternatively another community licence. These guidelines have been effectively operating since about 1978 and have had bipartisan support, and they are strongly supported by the industry representative body, that is, the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier this year in Queensland the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal refused the grant of a community licence to what was in essence a special interest group, a Christian applicant, on the ground that the group, so narrowly focused, was not suitable to hold a community licence. To return to Wynyard, subsequently the Christian FM Broadcasters amended its constitution and proposal to reflect the need to become more broadly based. This change by Christian FM Broadcasters has removed concern that its application for a community licence ought not be invited on the ground that the proposal would not be appropriate for community service. So far so good. But a second issue which has to be addressed is the fact that there are now two groups proposing to provide a community radio service. The other group is based in Burnie and is seeking to serve substantially the same area as that proposed by Christian FM Broadcasters.

Although my Department has in the past advised both groups that it will be recommending that two community licences be invited to the same area, the planning guidelines, as I have indicated, state that only one licence should be invited. The approach is to provide for a logical phased development of new services. It needs to be borne in mind that at some stage in the near future-the year is yet to be specified-a commercial FM licence will come to the north-west of Tasmania. Competition for revenue from the local market between commercial AM and FM stations, as well as a community station, is likely to be intense and the area is not one, as the Senate knows, regrettably, of rapid economic development. It is, therefore, not appropriate at this stage to be contemplating more than one community licence for the area.

My office has had extensive consultation with both the Wynyard and Burnie groups in recent months, as Senator Archer is acknowledging, attempting to get the groups to join together. If both are genuine community broadcasters, this, in all the circumstances, would seem the obvious and sensible thing to do. The alternative is for the groups to enter into an adversarial contest before the ABT as to which group should be awarded the licence. I conclude my swan song by asking Senator Archer to use his good office to encourage the groups to combine. Whatever the outcome, I can say, to put the matter beyond doubt, that applications will be invited for a community radio service to cover the north-west Tasmania area no later than October. The only question is whether the two of them will fight it out or whether they can agree to go in as one.

SPEECH.PARA: For another-and in the absence of accompanying spending cuts-there is a growing question whether . . . the Treasurer's promised major tax cuts can really be (responsibly) delivered next July.
The second quote is as follows:
Any real tax cut in 1989-90-
That is, next financial year-
(unaccompanied by more less equivalent cuts in government spending) must result in a sharp reduction in the Budget surplus.

Even by the Minister for Finance's standards, the misrepresentation contained in his statement to the Senate this afternoon that in that article I was rebutting the view of the Leader of the Opposition is more than usually gross.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation. Yesterday in the House of Representatives the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen)-after correctly noting that I was well known-falsely claimed that I had written letters to councils supporting the proposal for the recognition of local government to be decided at next Saturday's referendum. This is absolutely false and is the latest of a long list of dirty tricks the Government has used in its dishonest referendum campaign. My letters of support for appropriate constitutional recognition of local government followed submissions to me from several councils that sought the kind of recognition that would protect their position in four key matters. These submissions were also made to the Hawke Government and to the Constitutional Commission. As stated in the letter from the Wollongong City Council to me these matters of concern are:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The ability of the State Government to dismiss a properly elected Council, without public enquiry and without the views of the Council or the electors being heard.
2. The denial of any right of appeal for a dismissed Council or any avenue to seek to question the State Government's grounds for dismissal.

3. The statutory vesting of powers in the State Government in relation to matters of local zoning, rezonings, certain development applications and the removal of all planning functions despite the position occupied by Local Government as the most responsive to and most aware of local public opinion.

4. The setting by the State Government of maximum permissible annual rate increases which can severely inhibit the revenue raising ability of Councils to meet day to day expenditure on local works and services.

The Hawke Government rejected each one of these four points with the result that the proposal to be put in Saturday's referendum contains not one of the key issues councils wrote to me about, which, of course, were the issues that prompted me to write a letter of general support to the councils. It is, therefore, patently dishonest for Mr Bowen or anyone else to pretend that my support for meaningful recognition of local government means that I support the present farcical proposal that does not meet even one of the council's main objectives. Mr Bowen's deception in this matter is yet another act of desperation to get these crooked proposals through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) from making a statement relating to the Government's Offsets Program.

I waited for Senator Button to make a statement at the conclusion of Question Time, but he did not do so. I feel I have an absolute obligation to industry to call upon Senator Button to clarify the confusion which he has created about this entire program. Let me explain. In the Senate during the Appropriation debate of 19 November last year, Senator Button said that he would make a statement about the partnership for development agreements in due course. Again, on Tuesday, 30 August this year, the Minister in response to a question of mine said:
I shall try to put together a statement relating to the details.

It appears that the Minister today will not be making that statement in the Senate and that the Senate and the Australian people will have to wait until the end of next month-it will be nearly four weeks before we sit again-or, if he does not bother to make it then, they may have to wait until October or November, or even some future stage, for him to make a statement about this matter.

This is a matter of great importance. It involves multi-million dollar agreements, apparently entered into between multinational companies and this Government, agreements which the Minister told us yesterday are not contractual arrangements. He said that they are some other form of agreement. As a lawyer, I do not know what is an agreement which is not a contractual arrangement. Even an agreement which is not in writing, once consideration passes, becomes a contract. These agreements are, in fact, in writing. The Minister has made a statement, to the Estimates committees, in press releases or in the Senate to the effect that an agreement has been executed. Yet the day before yesterday, in this Parliament, the Minister said that there are no binding commercial contracts and that it is not intended to be that way. It is an arrangement between the Commonwealth and international information industry companies as to how they do business in Australia. If that is an agreement in writing and if it is binding on these people and on the Government, the people of Australia are entitled to know what are the terms and whether it can be broken. After all, we are dealing with hundreds of millions of dollars.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts has already pointed to the opportunities that exist in the offsets program for corruption. I am not accusing anyone in Australia of being involved in corruption, but the opportunities are enormous. We know that in the United States of America, in regard to the Lockheed Company, for example, in its arrangements and dealings with Japan, there was massive corruption. Here there are opportunities which abound. This involves megabucks. We are not talking about one million dollars or half a million dollars. We are talking about tens of millions of dollars, and indeed of hundreds of millions of dollars. I believe that the people of Australia are entitled to know whether these agreements are in writing or not, whether they can be broken on notice, and what are their terms and conditions.

The second point I wish to make relates to the absolute confusion which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has created in the minds of those of us who have tried to apply our minds to what the Minister has been saying about these agreements as to what on earth are their terms and conditions. Yesterday, the Minister added to the confusion about the nature and content of these agreements by making statements which conflict with earlier statements. Previously he had made statements which conflicted with even earlier statements. One has to ask Senator Button whether he really knows what these agreements are all about. Having heard what he has said in this chamber about these matters, one suspects that he has not really grasped the nature of the agreements which he is executing on behalf of the people of Australia.

Let me elaborate. I ask the Minister: Is the export performance requirement of the partnership agreements a simple 50 per cent export-import ratio, as the Minister told Estimates Committee A on 12 April 1988, and also in a Press release dated 7 April 1988? Secondly, is it a requirement for Australian value added exports to be equal to 50 per cent of imports, as the Minister admitted to Estimates Committee A later on 19 April 1988, when subjected to questioning by my colleague Senator Alston? Thirdly, is it a requirement for the average Australian content of exports to exceed 70 per cent over the range of export activities, as the Minister told the Senate last Tuesday.

Let me explain what those three propositions mean in the sort of language used by ordinary people. In regard to a simple 50 per cent export-import ratio, I gave the Minister an example the other day when I referred to somebody importing $1 million worth of goods, re-exporting the same goods and then re-importing the same million dollars worth of goods. In that way the person concerned has achieved a 50 per cent export-import ratio.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I point out to Senator Lewis that he is speaking on the motion as to why Standing Orders should be suspended. The Senate is being treated to a whole debate in a contribution as to why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Yes, Mr President, because it is vital that the Minister gives the answers to these questions. I can go on to explain that the second alternative adopted by the Minister was a situation where one imports, say, $2m worth of goods and exports $1m worth of goods, 50 per cent in Australian value added goods. That was another explanation given by the Minister. Finally, we had the Minister's third explanation yesterday when he said, `No, that is not right. One imports goods worth $2m; one has then to export $1m worth of goods: and, of those exports, some 70 per cent of the goods has to be Australian value added. That means one has 70 per cent of 50 per cent as Australian value added'. This is a matter of vital importance which the Minister should explain to the Senate. The people of Australia should not have to wait until October or November-some vague time in the future-when the Minister might get round to giving this explanation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not agree to the suspension of Standing Orders in relation to this matter. It was only some three days ago that I told Senator Lewis that I was quite happy to bring down a statement on this matter, and I shall do so at the earliest opportunity the moment the Senate resumes. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to defeat the Hawke Government's deceitful second referendum proposal which, if successful, would empower it to alter the electoral systems of each of the six States to ensure the election of Labor governments.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of Senator Messner. Of all the deceitful questions that will be put to the people on Saturday, I think that question No. 2 is probably the most deceitful of all, because it sounds the most attractive and plausible. I was interested to hear, during Question Time, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, talk about the result of a poll of over 3,000 school children in Tasmania. That was the only question that was resolved in the affirmative by the children. It was the most attractive; it seemed to offer the best lolly.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity to draw the Senate's attention to the whole result of the poll, which was conducted in 45 schools in my State. Senator Tate and I contributed to the columns of the Launceston Examiner for five weeks, stating the case for and against the four questions. I convinced the school children that questions 1, 3 and 4 should be answered in the negative. Senator Tate just managed to convince the children that question 2 on fair and democratic elections should be resolved in the affirmative but the children were attracted by the lolly and it is a very deceitful question. Who would not be attracted to the idea of fair and democratic elections? One has to be doubtful about it when one knows that the Australian Democrats support it. That immediately makes one wonder just what is behind it. The legislation does not define democratic. People are not told that this is only going to apply to the States. People are not told that it is just not going to do anything about the skilfully drawn but biased boundaries. What this question really is about is Canberra running States' elections. It will do nothing to guarantee free and democratic elections and that is what the people are being asked about. They are not being told what it is really about.

A lot of people in this country do not even realise that States do have constitutions of their own. It always surprises people if one asks, `Why do we need something like this in the Federal Constitution, we have got it in the States?' We know here that at Federation the States gave certain limited powers away to the Commonwealth. This was one they did not give away, they still do not wish to give it away but this Federal Government is not happy with its powers. It wants to take more power than it was given at Federation. It is pretty typical I suppose of Federal governments, but constantly people around Australia say no to more power to the Federal Government and they should do so this time because this will once again change the balance of power between Canberra and the States. This Federal Government does not happen to like the electoral systems in Queensland, Tasmania and Western Australia so it wants to change the rules of the game. These rights should not be handed over. They were not handed over at Federation and they should not be handed over now.
I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a comment by Mr Malcolm Mackerras in the Weekend Australian on 6-7 August. He said:

The second proposal, fair elections . . . represents the ultimate in centralism. If carried it will mean that the people of the States will not even be allowed to determine for themselves the kind of electoral system by which they are governed . . . I have no right to tell the Tasmanians how they should elect their State Parliament. I could give myself that right by a yes vote to fair elections but I will not do so. Only the people of each State should determine the electoral system of that State.
The Tasmanians have a unique electoral system which they know and like.

We are concerned in my State, as many of the other States are, about this intrusion of a government from the centre which does not really understand local problems and interests. We say that foreigners, and sometimes we in Tasmania mean mainlanders by that, do not know what is best for the local scene. We had a very good example of this when the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) came to Tasmania. The first law officer of the land, the man one would expect to really understand the electoral systems of this country, the man who is proposing these so-called free and democratic elections had no idea of the structure of the Tasmanian Legislative Council or how it was elected.

I draw honourable senator's attention to the fact that he told journalists that and it was reported in the Australian newspaper. He did not know what the impact of his proposed so-called reforms would be on the upper House in Tasmania. He did not know how the reforms would be implemented. I believe that this is a pretty poor thing for somebody who is up there, up front, who wants the States to surrender their electoral rights. There are people, like him, who want the nation to follow the rules from Canberra but he does not even have an understanding at all of how the parliamentary systems work in his own country.

For the record, let me just tell honourable senators how the Tasmanian system does work. I believe that it is a very fair system and I am not now talking about the lower House which is well known to have the fairest electoral system of any lower House in the country. I am talking now of the upper House which is the object of the Federal Government's attention in this referendum proposal. The Legislative Council in Tasmania has a fixed term with an annual rotational system. There are 19 members of the upper House, they are single member constituencies, they serve the six year terms and each May polls are held for three of the seats and the election for four seats is held in every sixth year in order to make up the 19. All but one of those people are independents. The one is a Labor man. Not only is the Deputy Prime Minister's ignorance worrying but the overall history of question 2, just by itself, is alarming. I do not think that the Federal Government's right hand knows what its left hand is doing. Let us remember just what happened in this place during those drawn-out debates that we had rushed through the night: Bills being brought in, found to be wanting, taken away again, other ones put on and guillotines proposed so that there was limited time for debating any one issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Supported by the Democrats.
—Supported by the Democrats loving their free democracy; very hypocritical.
—The far Left of the Labor Party.

—Thank you Senator Parer, that is quite right. Let us remember what happened to this proposal. This is a piece of legislation that has already gone through this House, that is supposed to give us free and democratic elections and that the Government brought in. Thanks to Senator Vanstone the Government suddenly learnt that its proposal clashed with its own proposals for an electoral system in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT).
—They did it with such a rush.

—They did it with such a rush, exactly, and their drafting was pretty much up the creek of course. It was a hurried thing. The Government originally recommended that where an election is State wide or single member electorates the voting system should be preferential. But the d'Hondt system that they were proposing for the ACT is non-preferential. So the Government hastily amended its referendum Bill and that was not too good either so then the Democrats had a go. Now the Bill does allow for non-preferential voting systems for the ACT but still the Democrat proposals probably offend the constitutional proposals even now. Senator Vanstone, today during the lunch time debate, set this out very clearly. I draw people's attention to the clear manner in which she set out the dilemma for voting in the ACT and how we need to get a system which will be free, fair and democratic. This Government is not providing it. How democratic is it when the second choice of Australians need not be counted? That cannot be called an equal or a democratic vote if the second choice does not count for anything. We just cannot allow such a patched up and ill-considered amendment to be added for posterity to our Constitution. If we act in haste we are going to repent at leisure.

SPEECH.PARA: This simply takes the matter of elections out of the flexible sphere of State legislation and puts them in concrete in our Constitution where it becomes a Federal Government imposition on the people in the States. What is democratic about an electoral system which in 1987 the Australian Labor Party with 45.83 per cent of the vote got 86 seats in the Federal election and the coalition with more votes, 46.07 per cent, only got 62 seats. I remind honourable senators that that was after the Australian Electoral Commission had spent three years going around this country and told us at the end of it that we now had free, fair, equal electorates. After getting numerically equal electorates, according to the Electoral Commissioner, that was the imbalance in the votes that we achieved. For the ALP to win an election in Victoria it needs 48.7 per cent. It needs 47.8 per cent in South Australia and 46.5 per cent in Western Australia. What the Government proposes is equal electorates but it is not proposing equal representation. Its proposal will not remove gerrymandering. In 1987 the majority report of the inquiry of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters into the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill acknowledged, and I quote:

The enactment of electoral laws limiting enrolment differences between electorates to an arbitrary 10 per cent would not prevent or eliminate the gerrymandering of electoral boundaries for the political advantages of one group.

Of course that is right and at best the 20 per cent margin will mean reshuffling of the existing gerrymanders. I would like to draw the Senate's attention to the situation again in Tasmania where there is a seat on the west coast of Tasmania, a very isolated area, known as the seat of Gordon in the upper House. It has 6,502 electors. Compare that with Pembroke which has the largest number of electors and that is 18,682. But there is a very good and proper reason for Gordon to turn in one member of the upper House and for Pembroke to return an equal number. I think it is very similar to the argument that we, in the smaller States, should have the same number of senators as the bigger States. There are special interests that need representation that otherwise would not be heard. Gordon is that sort of seat. It is isolated. It is a mining community with no unity of interests with any other group or area anywhere near it. It is difficult to get to and would not easily be served by somebody who lived in another area.

Tasmanians are happy with that system. There has been no complaint from Tasmanians that there is unfairness. They recognise the justice of the miners and the hydroelectric workers on the west coast getting a member to represent just their interests. That area is a great contributor to our economy; it is very important to us. Those people who work with their hands-and I would have thought that this Government would be interested in them, but clearly it is not-deserve to be heard, but the Australian Labor Party will not facilitate that.

It is interesting that in debates in Tasmania, Federal Labor members have not appeared at all, with the occasional exception of Senator Tate. But Mr Patmore, a Labor member of the lower House in Tasmania, was prepared to debate with me at one public meeting I spoke at. He was adamant that Tasmania's representation in the Senate deserved to remain equal with that of all the other States. He had great difficulty in applying that same principle to the people in Gordon. The people in the audience roared at him and questioned him constantly during question time. Tasmanians do not seem to see things through the eyes of people like Senator Devereux, who spoke to us on Tuesday about what he said was the lack of Tasmanian support for the No case. He told us that there was nobody much up front in Tasmania supporting it. Yet only a week or so ago the Legislative Council having debated all four questions, by an overwhelming vote recommended four Noes. Senator Devereux is not the only one who has not been accepting any invitations to public meetings in Ulverstone, Devonport, Burnie, Launceston or Hobart-none of the Labor members have been fronting up to those public meetings, none have appeared on talkback radio. Senator Tate was the only person prepared to debate with me on Christian radio-and he had to be asked three times. Senator Devlin was heard on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio recently saying that there was no need for politicians in the debate and that we should not want politicians in it because it was only a debate for the people. Mr Bowen said that only yesterday.

This Government does not want people to know what the real issues are. It knows that when people realise that it means more power for Canberra, they will not want a bar of it. The Government was hoping this whole matter would slip through and people would not know anything about it. I draw honourable senators' attention to the debate I was talking about in the Legislative Council in Tasmania. One of the people supporting the No vote was the former Labor Premier of Tasmania, the Honourable Doug Low. I hope that Senator Devereux will take a bit of notice of that-a former colleague, or at least a former member of his party, when he was being truly independent recognised what is in the best interests of our State. Mr Bowen tells us that he knows best. He says that our Legislative Council perhaps could be expanded from 19, representing electorates of a variety of sizes. We do not want that, Tasmanians do not want that. It is a lot of nonsense.

I have miles of things I would like to say about the dirty tricks this Government has played to try to get this proposition slipped through. Mr Hawke is now trying to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat. He intends to take a higher profile in the referendum campaign. I hope he does because he will fail. The Federal Government's duplicity in this matter is amazing. I thank God that the latest polls show that. This deceitful proposal simply has to be defeated.

In the end, it has meant that the Opposition, the coalition, has no real policies, and if it goes to the lowest common denominator there is no way that any electorate will support it.

Let us look at the history of this issue of malapportionment. It has been the Labor Party that has been in the vanguard of reform. At the Federal level it was the Whitlam Government that pushed for 10 per cent maximum differences in boundaries. As soon as the Whitlam Government went out, what did Fraser do? he introduced the 5,000 square kilometre provision that again distorted electorates. In spite of what was written in his policy statement he brought that distortion in at the behest of Doug Anthony and Ian Sinclair. We had to have it right up until 1983. Having been elected in 1983 we introduced into this Parliament-and it was supported by those opposite-a 10 per cent rule based on population growth. Those opposite are on the record in Hansard as supporting that proposal and recognising it as one of the fairest methods of redistribution in Australia's history. I assume that support for the Federal system is maintained today. That is basically what we are trying to translate into the various States.

Looking at the States, virtually all the progress that has been made in those States has been made by the Labor Party. Everyone says that in South Australia Steele Hall was a great reformer. However, when he left office seats were still badly malapportioned in that State. It was one of the worst gerrymanders in Australia. It was up to the Dunstan Government to remove those inequities. Until 1982 the Victorian boundaries were always country favoured. The Cain Government remedied that. Again, the Liberal Party, in the Victorian Legislative Council, did not object to a 10 per cent rule. It supported it on that occasion. TALK.START.PARA: —Why did Tonkin resign?

—In Western Australia the Liberal Party has a tragic history of frustrating any attempts at electoral reform. Senator Crichton-Browne and the cronies he put in the Legislative Council, in the days when he controlled the Liberal Party in Western Australia-before Senator Chaney's mob took over and humiliated him-in the days he used to be the big man in Western Australia, prevented electoral reform there.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look right throughout Australia at the tragic history of electoral reform the State that stands out the most is Queensland. (Quorum formed) If ever there were a State where the Liberal Party should hang its head in shame it is Queensland. The form of malapportionment and gerrymandering in Queensland has several basic objectives. The first objective is probably to keep the Labor Party out of power. For those opposite that would be no real problem. The second imperative is to ensure that the National Party always wins more seats than the Liberal Party. The party that is most disadvantaged by the malapportionment in Queensland is the Liberal Party. For a number of years, from 1957 to 1983, the Liberal Party was in coalition with the Nationals as the junior member. Yet, at several State elections it achieved a far higher popular vote than did the National Party. The Liberal Party was kept in the junior ranks of the coalition simply by the malapportionment and gerrymander.

From time to time there would be the odd rebellion. From time to time the odd Liberal would get up and squawk about the unfair boundaries. But the fact is that the behaviour of the Liberal Party in Queensland from 1957 to 1983 was the most craven behaviour of any political party in Australia's history. It was behaviour of absolute submission, of absolute embarrassment-to countenance a situation continuing in which it was deprived of being the major governing party in the State simply because of a desire to have a few Ministers, to have the deputy premiership. Never once, in spite of countless offers from the other side, did its members cross the floor and fix up the situation in Queensland. Apparently, that activity has finally come to a halt. Mr Innes has indicated that he will be voting Yes. And what do his Federal colleagues do, after 31 years of craven cowardice? They betray him. They let him down. They leave him holding the bag. That is the reality of the situation in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can introduce a private member's Bill himself.
—Senator Crichton-Browne talks about introducing a private member's Bill. Would it have taken 31 years to draft a private member's Bill? Really! How long does it take to draft such a Bill?
—They want to get it right.

—Senator Boswell and his ilk in Queensland can never win on an even playing field. They make politics the handicap. They must have a head start to win in Queensland. Once they start by corrupting the electoral boundaries it is little wonder that corruption starts to edge out into every other section of society in Queensland. It is little wonder that every second or third policeman in Queensland is in the joke, on the take. That is what the National Party has presided over in Queensland, based on crooked electoral boundaries. In Queensland corruption has become a byword-the State with the white shoe brigade and its corrupt practices. Fancy Sir Terence Lewis getting a knighthood! The only good thing about that is that he was the only one in Queensland never to pay for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that the degree of cronyism and corruption in Queensland is such that its only parallels are current day Romania and Louisiana in the 1930s, we put the proposal to the people of Australia that we wanted it to change. We want fair electoral boundaries in Queensland. That is what we will be voting for on Saturday. It is not good enough to say that this is merely a States rights matter. What does `States rights' mean? What they should mean is the protection of people's rights, the rights of Australian citizens. What we are putting to the Australian people this coming Saturday is a method to undo the corrupt electoral boundaries in Queensland.

I want to say only two other things. Time and again the red herring of the difference between malapportionment and gerrymanders is dragged across this chamber. Those opposite say, `This legislation will not get rid of gerrymanders'. That is true only to a point. One of the great tools of gerrymander is malapportionment. By removing malapportionment we reduce enormously any possibility for a gerrymander, although we do not exclude it absolutely. The way to exclude it absolutely is to appoint fair commissioners. I point to examples of fair commissioners appointed at a Federal level and in my own State of Victoria, where in 1984 we appointed such commissioners. We had equal boundaries. We ended up worse off than we were with the 1982 boundaries. We do not complain about that. But there are our bona fides. We were able to appoint independent commissioners, but through the luck of the draw in the drawing of the boundaries we were, if you like, temporarily disadvantaged coming into the 1985 election.
The final point I wish to raise is this question of dirty tricks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The deceitful question.

—The deceitful question; a few more cliches from the shadow Minister should round out my speech. We are supposed to be guilty of that. If ever I have seen an underhanded smearing campaign I have seen it this time. Those opposite have never sought to confront the basic issues of the referendum. They have gone down every by way of deception and drawn every red herring they can find rather than confront the issues. Never has it been more clearly evinced than in question No. 2, but they are too ashamed to confront that issue. We have seen all sorts of distortions appear when this fear and smear campaign has been run by those opposite. One only has to look at the composition of the Opposition task force to see that it has drawn on the dark side of coalition politics. All those who are professional vicious right wingers within the Liberal Party attempted to get a berth on that one.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who have used those terror tactics within the Liberal Party are now exporting their skills into the electorate and latching on to the fears that exist there. I pointed out in Question Time yesterday that even the despised Queensland National Party, with its rotten corruption, with its white shoe brigade, its crook fund raising methods, its relationship with crooked policemen, with all of its humiliation of the last few months, still has had the decency to stand up and condemn the League of Rights. It has still had the decency to say that this organisation will pervert democracy in this country. Yet at the same time the Liberal Party propaganda, distributed in Western Australia with Mr Peter Reith's authorisation, is put out in the League of Rights publication. When we check with that organisation and publication, they are doing so at the request of the West Australian Liberals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at my request.

—I invite Senator Crichton-Browne, if he is speaking in this debate, to repudiate that organisation and its involvement in this referendum campaign. It shows how desperate those opposite are to debate these proposals that they could go to such a despised and despicable organisation as the League of Rights.
—Like you said, I don't run the show.
—I said that Senator Crichton-Browne did not run the show, but there is always a possibility of a comeback.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this note: I regard and always have regarded question No. 2 as the most important question. It will eliminate a blight on Australian democracy. We in this country were historically the leaders in developing sophisticated democratic processes in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. In recent years at a Federal level we have been leading much of the world. If we make this achievement on Saturday, we can again hold our heads high as a country that cares about democracy, a country that can go to any international forum in the world and point to our own democratic institutions as being clean and above suspicion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance that reads in a rather hilarious fashion:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to defeat the Hawke Government's deceitful second referendum proposal which, if successful-
that is the fair and democratic elections proposal-
would empower it to alter the electoral systems of each of the six States to ensure the election of Labor Governments.

In other words, it is an admission that if there were fair boundaries somehow or other the Australian Labor Party would get elected. Why anyone would put up such a proposal is extraordinary. Even more extraordinary, of course, is the history of this exercise. This will be the last chance I have to speak on this matter in this chamber before the people vote on Saturday.

I am reminded that the campaign I started on this goes back some five years now to the private member's Bill I introduced in the old Parliament House. I remember well the debate we had in trying to get that up and running. I remember well the fact that my private member's Bill was the only private member's Bill ever discussed at the Constitutional Convention. I remember the feeling of elation when finally the vote was forced on my private member's Bill in the convention in Brisbane and it was supported by an overwhelming majority of those at the convention. I was happy therefore when, after the reference of my Bill twice to a joint committee-we had an election half-way through that inquiry-finally the Government chose to move and put to the people for their deliberation this most fundamental question.

It is important to realise what is in this question. There are two items. One is a guarantee of adult franchise-the first time in Australia's history that there will be a constitutional guarantee of adult franchise. Indeed, my own State in 1899 had a very intensive campaign to stay out of the Federation. The central point of that campaign was that the Constitution that was proposed did not enshrine adult franchise. Since then, at the behest of politicians, half of the population-that is, women-have been given the right to vote. I say `given the right to vote' because it was given to them by politicians not as a right, which it should have been, but because it was felt that that was the thing to be done.

Since that time, people who went to war to defend this country and had never had a say in electing the government of the country they were asked to die for, have been given the right to vote. How demeaning, how sickening, that people who were considered good enough to die for the country did not have the right to vote as a constitutional right as citizens of this country. Let us be very clear: one of the items in the second question aims to enshrine in our Constitution that most fundamental of rights-that every adult in this country because he is a citizen, not because he is male, not because he is of a particular age, not because he has property, but because he is a citizen, has the right to elect the government that will govern this country. That is in the second question. That is ignored by the Opposition parties.

The other question is an attempt, and a first attempt admittedly, to move down the road to enshrine a range of rules by which politicians will get their jobs. The Opposition is saying politicians should keep those powers. I believe that there should be more of these enshrined in the Constitution. I have made a range of proposals, only some of which, of course, are in this particular question. I believe there should be another item to deal with the problem of gerrymander, which could be dealt with not in such a direct way but by saying that any redistribution had to be done on fair and non-partisan boundaries. There is a range of ways of dealing with these issues. On question No. 2, the fundamental question for the people on Saturday is: do you want politicians to have the total say about how they will draw up the rules? It is a little like saying to one football team, `You draw up the rules and then we will have a game'. Surely in any exercise in this country where we believe in a fair go it is reasonable to say that the ground rules should be fair and that the people who win are the legitimate winners.

In my own State I am pleased to say that the Liberal Party is campaigning for a yes vote; the Labor Party is campaigning for a yes vote; the Australian Democrats are campaigning for a yes vote. It is only the National Party, whose hide is at stake, that is campaigning for a no vote. Why is it campaigning for a no vote? It is very clear that it could not win government unless it rigged and rorted the boundaries. People then say, `Well, all right then, it's a matter of States rights; States should be able to decide these things'. What legitimacy is there in that proposition when a State for some 60 years has rigged and rorted the boundaries? We then say, `It still has the right to continue to do that'. If it ever had the right, and I dispute that, it forfeited it a long time ago when it decided that it would continue to rig and rort the boundaries to keep itself in political power. We have seen the results of that rorting exercise. It is displayed every day in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Brisbane.

Why is there a connection between corruption in the police force and the electoral system? Is that not a bit of a long hop? It is not, and I will tell honourable senators why. One of the basic safeguards in a democratic community is that the government in power can always lose the next election. That keeps it honest; that keeps its nose to the grindstone; and that keeps its hands out of people's pockets. It is because a government can lose office; nothing else. We must never be beguiled by the fact that members of a government all happen to be nice people who are always looking after us. We have to ride shotgun when we put politicians into power. The way that our democracy has decided to do that is to say: `In a couple of years' time, mate, your skin is on the line again, so keep your nose clean'. That is what democracy does. That is why we have got away from dictatorships and autocracies-because they have never had to worry about those types of things. That is the genius of democracy.

If a government can go to the people and not have to worry-it could say, `They know we are coming back. Let us go through the charade yet again. We have rigged the system and we will be back in power, mate'-of course it will start looking elsewhere; there is no bind on it. That sort of government is then in exactly the same situation as a dictator. Nobody is riding shotgun on the politicians; they are out of control. We have seen in Queensland why that is the case.

I think either Senator Crichton-Browne or Senator Boswell asked by way of interjection, `Who is looking after us now? Why did the Fitzgerald inquiry happen?' With all due respect, it happened to be because of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. It was not because of the National Party of Australia. It was because some crusading journalist decided to get out there and spill the beans. And when he did, there was nowhere to go. There had to be an inquiry, and, day after day, that inquiry is turning up the very sorry events in my State.

That is why we need to look carefully at this issue and why we need, finally, to say yes to the second referendum question. I would be the first to acknowledge that it does not do everything. Indeed, I have private member's Bills in this chamber which I believe would vastly improve the representation of people not only in this Parliament but also in other parliaments. I will not stand up here and pretend that it does everything that I would like, or that it goes as far as I would like, but it is a start down the road to entrenching a set of rules by which politicians will get their jobs, not only here but also in other jurisdictions.

The point about power going to Canberra has been made again in this debate. I find that absolutely extraordinary for anybody who has read the legislation. Why is that? The reason is that if the second question is passed on Saturday, this Parliament will lose powers that it currently has. It will lose powers that it has exercised, and they will be entrenched in the Constitution and no longer available to it. This chamber will lose powers on that second question, as will the House of Representatives. We will no longer be able to vary the percentage. We will no longer be able, if we wish, to put in particular propositions about how people should draw up boundaries. We will no longer be able, if we wish, to take away the independence of the Australian Electoral Commission so that we can get at the boundaries and change them in a way that suits the majority in this Parliament.

This Parliament, in proposing that act to the people, is in fact proposing to divest itself of powers, not take on powers. It is true that it is also seeking to divest State parliaments of certain powers and entrench those powers in the Constitution. That seems to me to be the first step towards further democratic reforms in our society. Surely all of us have to be conscious of one overriding fact: democracies in the world are shrinking in number year by year. We have seen the unhappy events in our own region, in Fiji, where democracy has been seen to be so brittle before the point of a gun. We must never be complacent enough, just because we have built this type of edifice to house our Parliament, to think that this Parliament House, somehow or other, because of its momentum and size, will protect democracy. Democracy in this country can be protected only by the will of the people, and we have to do everything we can to entrench, to strengthen and to develop our democratic traditions.

I hark back to those people who drew up the Federal Constitution; to those people who had the foresight to propose a federation for this country; to those people who had the foresight to propose innovations, such as the secret ballot; and to those people who had the foresight to propose a whole range of items adopted elsewhere in the world as fundamental democratic traditions. Why now, in 1988, should we be fearful of taking a further step to entrench democratic traditions so that those who follow afterwards will be able to thank us for continuing the fight for what is the best system in the world-the system by which the citizens of any country rule themselves?

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance which has been put forward by Senator Newman is in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to defeat the Hawke Government's deceitful second referendum proposal which, if successful, would empower it to alter the electoral system of each of the six States to ensure the election of Labor governments.
The long title of the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988 is:
An Act to alter the constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia.

That is so blatantly dishonest, so blatantly misleading and so blatantly intended to induce a Yes vote that it is breathtaking in its audacity. If for no other reason, it ought to be defeated because of the dishonesty and the deception with which the Government is putting this proposal.

I pick up a couple of matters raised by Senator Robert Ray. He talks about dirty tricks. I remind him that the last time we had some proposals to amend the Constitution, Senator Gareth Evans proposed an appropriation of $2m of taxpayers' money to promote the Yes case, but nothing was proposed for the No case. When we asked for it he said, `No. The Australian electorate is conservative and if it is to be persuaded, it is with the taxpayers' money that we will do it'. He said that the No case started with a head start. Today Senator Peter Walsh asked the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to withdraw funds from the Queensland Government and from the Queensland people because that Government has had the audacity to try to put the other side of the argument honestly, as it is; to go past the dishonesty of the proposal which is being put.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might try withdrawing $120m in funds from the Western Australian Government.

—Yes-do the same thing with Western Australia and see what would happen. That particular constitutional amendment proposal was dropped because the coalition moved an amendment to a consequential Bill and defeated that objective.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray said that the Australian Labor Party has maintained the integrity of electoral reform in Australia. No doubt he is one of the architects of this legislation. I remind him that it was this Government that sought to increase the size of the House of Representatives and, subsequently, the size of the Senate, not because there was an argument in support of this from an electoral point of view, not because it was required from a representative point of view, but simply because a judgment had been made that the boundaries could be drawn within an increased size of the House of Representatives to it advantage-Machiavellian as you like; certainly nothing to do with altruism. Senator Robert Ray also referred to Brian Burke as the initiator of electoral reform in Western Australia. I just remind Senator Ray that it was Arthur Tonkin, the then Minister in charge of electoral reform, who resigned from Cabinet and ultimately from Parliament because, as he said himself, Labor Premier Brian Burke of Western Australia was not serious in his intentions. In fact, Mr Burke said at a Cabinet meeting held in Geraldton, Western Australia: `Let us put up a Bill that the Opposition will be compelled to defeat. Let us ensure that we do not have electoral reform'. That is why Arthur Tonkin resigned from the Labor Cabinet.

I turn for a moment to some fundamentals. Senator Robert Ray said that there is a distinction between a gerrymander and malapportionment and that we confuse the two. Let us look at Western Australia in relation to the House of Representatives on the basis that, as is already the case, there is, with a tolerance, one vote one value. What has happened in Western Australia at the Federal level over the past couple of elections compared with the last State election? On the last occasion that there were 10 House of Representatives seats for Western Australia, the Liberal and National parties achieved 57 per cent of the vote and, with that 57 per cent, 90 per cent of the seats. At the last election the Labor Party succeeded with slightly more than 50 per cent of the primary vote, and obtained 70 per cent of the members. Today Senator Robert Ray told the Senate that gerrymandering is not important, that it is malapportionment that we need to change. That is quite untrue. If we look at the Legislative Assembly in that gerrymandered State of Western Australia, we find that the difference between the number of seats held by the successful government and its primary vote has never varied by more than 7 or 8 per cent. So with all the best will in the world on the part of this Government the system in Western Australia at the moment succeeds far in excess of the Government's proposal.

The tragedy is that, if this Government cannot be trusted to put the constitutional amendment proposal up, what can it be trusted to do? One would have thought that, if there was one thing that this Government and the Parliament owe the people of Australia, it is to ensure that the questions as they are put for constitutional amendment reflect the effect of those changes. However, we find the Government repeating its hallmark and presenting a dishonest question which in no way reflects the results that it will achieve if the question is carried.

The truth of the matter is that this Government is not serious about this question, any more than it is with respect to question No. 3 or question No. 4-they are all sugar coating for question No. 1. If this Government was serious about its view with respect to one vote one value, we would see fundamental changes at the Federal level and we would see some changes to the Senate. Why do we not see these changes? If this Government was serious, it would apply the same measure of integrity to its own Parliament as it seeks to impose on the various States. Of course, it has chosen not to do that. However, if it provided for one vote one value with respect to the Senate, New South Wales would have 25 senators, Victoria 19, Queensland 12, South Australia 7, Western Australia 6, Tasmania 2 and the two Territories would have one each. If this Government was serious about electoral reform, it would seek to amend section 24 of the Constitution, which provides that each of the original States are entitled to a minimum of five seats. Why does the Government not do that?

As long as Tasmania has five seats in the House of Representatives, the fundamental principle of one vote one value is totally distorted. What is the Government's reason for that? Surely it is no longer arguing that five seats give Tasmania a clear and distinct voice in the House of Representatives. There are now almost 150 members in the House of Representatives, so reducing Tasmania's quota from five members to three would not be noticed. However, the Government has not sought to do that, in the same way that it has not sought to change the Senate provision of each State having equal representation. It has not done that because it understands that some paramount and fundamental principles override the proposition of one vote one value, that is, particular areas of concern and responsibility. Each State has equal representation in the Senate to ensure that each State has an equal voice. Section 24 of the Constitution exists to ensure that Tasmania has a voice and so that Tasmanian members of the House of Representatives can represent the unique, distinct and separate considerations of their constituents and the aspirations, ambitions and ideals of Tasmania, in the same way that the Tasmanian senators represent 300,000 voters and New South Wales senators represent 3.5 million voters. No-one will argue that that is equity in terms of numbers. The truth of the matter is that it was recognised by our founding fathers and it is recognised now that each of the States has a unique and distinct characteristic which needs to be reflected in a fair and reasonable way in this Parliament.

There is something more than one vote one value, but of course the Government chooses not to deal with that problem. I really cannot explain why it does not have the courage to deal with the Senate except for reasons of political expediency. It cannot rely on its claim that it is a States House. Prime Minister Hawke and Mr Hayden both have called for it to be abolished and the Australian Democrats, the other supporters of the question, also have called for it to be abolished.

Before concluding, I wish to raise the matter of why this debate was not led by Senator Messner. Senator Messner put the proposition initially in Senator Newman's name and he was gentlemanly enough to step aside and let her commence the debate.

The report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing flows from a determination by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that there should be a reduction of $18m in the appropriations for the Parliament. As the report indicates, the first request was made on 1 August by the Minister for Finance, notwithstanding the fact, as I understand it, that officers of the Department of Finance had previously led the officers of the two Houses to believe that the appropriations which they had submitted were likely to be achieved. My first concern, Mr President, is that the request by the Minister for Finance to you and Madam Speaker was on 1 August, if my memory serves me correctly, some eight weeks after the bid was submitted by you and Madam Speaker. At that late stage, of course, it was impossible to deal with the matter properly.

Also, if my memory serves me correctly it was Estimates Committee A, which was chaired by Senator Graham Richardson, which proposed-and the motion was carried unanimously in this Parliament-that matters relating to the funding of the Senate ought to be the province of the Senate, and that in the event of some disagreement between the Treasury and the Senate the matter ought to be referred to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On this occasion it would have been Senator Button. That was not done because of the lateness of the hour of Senator Walsh, quite unilaterally and arbitrarily, taking $18m from the vote.

Senator Walsh on no occasion has sought to negotiate in a constructive way with you, Mr President, and Madam Speaker or the Appropriations and Staffing Committee. When you and Madam Speaker wrote back making it clear that it was impossible to make the cuts that Senator Walsh wanted, he wrote back and made some arbitrary suggestions, some of which were quite erroneous in their propositions. It is the view of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee that the cuts that have been made will significantly reduce the capacity of the Senate to function because the original bid that was made, was made, as I understand it, as the bottom line to what was necessary by way of appropriations for the proper functioning of the Senate.

I find it regrettable that on this occasion, Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, has chosen to ignore totally the motion of Estimates Committee A which was proposed in the Senate by Senator Richardson; that there has been no proper and constructive consultation; and, worse than that, the unilateral decision he has made in respect of the funding for the Senate provides decidedly less funding than the Senate's own Committee has judged that it needs. I would have thought that in this day and age, with the greater and growing intrusion of government, whether it be a Labor or Liberal government, into the management of the Parliament, it has never before been so necessary that the Parliament have the capacity and facility to scrutinise the activities and the functioning of government. We are fast reaching the point where that is no longer possible. One of the fundamental democratic principles that, presumably, most of us adhere to is the separation of powers between the Government and the Parliament.

As long as there is a government that will unilaterally decide what the funding for the Parliament should be, the connection between the two is such that there cannot be a proper separation of powers. As long as government has the capacity unilaterally to make cuts in the funding of the Parliament beyond that which allows the Senate to function properly, the powers of the Senate will be depleted. Senator Walsh has shown contempt before for the Senate, but it is very sad when I find it manifested in this way. It is a blatant example by this Government of its disregard for the Senate. That can lead in only one direction-the Senate will no longer have the capacity to monitor government in the way it should.

At a time when the Senate is being asked to cut back to the point where it cannot function properly, I am not aware-unless the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is on duty in the chamber at the moment, can enlighten me-of any significant cutbacks by the executive Government. I intend to pursue this in the Estimates hearings. I am not aware of any significant cut backs in the use of VIP aircraft; I am not aware of any cutbacks in expenditure in the executive wing of this building; I am not aware of any major cut- backs in travel allowances, either overseas or domestic, by any of the Ministers; I am not aware of any significant cutbacks by Ministers in respect of the use of Commonwealth cars; and I am not aware of any cutbacks that impinge upon or affect the executive Government. The argument, presumably, is that the Ministry needs increased funds because of increased responsibilities. At the same time it is reducing the Senate's funds and reducing its competence, its ability to function. I will be pursuing those matters and a number of others with some vigour at the Estimates hearings. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
