DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE MIDDLE EAST

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the official report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Middle East from 6 to 21 June 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

During June 1988, at the suggestion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), an all-party delegation of members of both Houses of the Parliament visited Syria, Jordan, Egypt and Israel. The delegation's principal task was to acquaint itself with the difficulties confronting the frontline states of the Middle East, including Israel. As well, the delegation was to express Australia's concern about human rights violations in the occupied territories and the additional difficulty these violations have created in achieving a just and lasting peace in the region.

The delegation's itinerary was an extremely busy one and we met with political leaders in all four countries, visited refugee camps in Syria, Jordan and the occupied territories and, during a tour of the occupied territories, the delegation visited two hospitals and met with a number of Palestinian groups. In addition, the delegation had the opportunity of seeing the strategic Golan Heights area from both the Syrian and Israeli sides.

In relation to a just and lasting settlement of the Middle East question, the delegation believes that such a settlement should be based on two fundamental points. The first is Israel's right to exist within secure and internationally recognised borders. The second is the recognition of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people to self-determination and, if they so choose, independence, including the possibility of their own independent state. The delegation's overriding impression is that while there is a sincere desire for peace in the region, agreement cannot, unfortunately, be reached on the process by which peace can be achieved. The delegation is firmly of the view that such an obstacle should not be allowed to stand in the way of a peaceful solution to the tragedy besetting the Middle East. In relation to the format that a peace conference should take, the delegation believes that an international conference under United Nations auspices will have sufficient authority to bring about a just and lasting peace settlement.

Prime Minister Shamir of Israel rejected outright the concept of an international conference and informed the delegation that Israel was ready to resume negotiations on the future of the occupied territories under the framework of the Camp David accords. In discussions with Arab leaders the delegation found only Egypt prepared to support the peace initiative proposed by Mr Shultz, the United States Secretary of State. However, Egypt, like all the Arab countries, sees Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) participation in any peace conference as essential. In Syria and Jordan there was little enthusiasm for the Shultz initiative, but both supported an international conference under United Nations auspices. Since the delegation's visit, announcements by King Hussein indicate that Jordan no longer regards the Shultz plan as viable.

The delegation believes that the Middle East problem will not be solved while Israel continues to deny the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people, including self-determination. It is unfortunate that Israel is now denying the Palestinian people the same rights for which the Jewish people fought so long and hard. The delegation fully appreciates the reluctance of Israel-having fought four wars since 1948-to place faith in peace agreements which may be negotiated with the Arab nations and the PLO. However, the delegation believes that the Arab states and the PLO are now, albeit reluctantly, prepared to accept the reality of Israel's existence. The delegation believes that both Israel and the PLO should take a major step towards peace by a simultaneous recognition of each other. The delegation is concerned about human rights violations in the occupied territories and believes that these will inevitably continue while the legitimate rights of Palestinians, including the right to their own independent state if they so choose, are denied.

The result of the forthcoming Israeli general election will be vital as it will determine the structure and policies of Israel. It appeared to the delegation that the formation of the National Unity Government, with equal Cabinet numbers from each political bloc, had led to a complete paralysis in relation to the Palestinian issue, as both Likud and Labour disagree on a number of issues, including the boundaries of Israel. Whilst the delegation was impressed with the vitality of Israeli democracy, it nevertheless wonders how long democratic ideals can be maintained while Israel governs, by force, the Palestinians of the occupied territories.

Following its visit to the Middle East, the delegation is pessimistic regarding the prospects for peace. The efforts of Mr Shultz seem to have run into a dead end and Mr Shamir shows no apparent flexibility on the subject of an international conference. In the meantime, it seems certain that the disturbances and the attendant loss of life will continue in the occupied territories, and that the gulf between Israelis and Palestinians will continue to widen. The delegation believes that the Australian Government should use every available means and opportunity at its disposal to encourage the parties to the conflict to seek an end to the Middle East dispute.

In conclusion, I would like to thank all members of the delegation for their support during the visit to the Middle East. The delegation worked extremely well together and all members made a significant contribution to the success of the visit. I would also like to express, on behalf of the delegation, my sincere thanks to the following Australian ambassadors and their staff for the tremendous amount of work done to ensure the success of the delegation. Their local knowledge and expert briefings were invaluable. I refer to Mr Ray Spurr in Damascus, Mr Terry Goggin in Amman, Mr Ian Hutchens in Cairo and Mr John Campbell in Tel Aviv. I should also like to thank the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office for organising the delegation's visit. On behalf of all members of the delegation, I publicly thank Mr Peter Roberts, the secretary to the delegation. The high quality of his administration was appreciated by all. Finally, I express the delegation's appreciation of fine work of its adviser, Mr Graham Bauer, of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The delegation found his experience of the Middle East invaluable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words about the parliamentary delegation to the Middle East, of which I was a member. I concur entirely with the remarks of my colleague and leader of the delegation, Senator Colston, and in large part I do not wish to go over ground he has already covered. I take the opportunity to place on record my thanks not only to the other members of the delegation but also in respect of the assistance we received from the secretary, Mr Peter Roberts, and our adviser, Mr Graham Bauer.

SPEECH.PARA: At about the time the delegation was concluding its visit to the Middle East it was reported to us that there had been comments in one of the Australian newspapers that the delegation to the Middle East was no more than an expensive junket at the taxpayers' expense that simply confirmed prejudices. I have not regarded it as my business to try to check or trace those comments. Certainly it was my strong impression that the visit was enormously beneficial in respect of my own visit. I learned a great deal from it. Obviously nothing replaces going to see for oneself or meeting the people, and I shall return to that topic. I am sure all members of the delegation will agree that we were not there as a junket, learning nothing and only confirming prejudices, but that we all learned a huge amount. Certainly any visit to the Golan Heights completely outweighs or replaces any prejudiced view. No amount of photographs or descriptions of that place can possibly convey how strategic and important the heights are in terms of military considerations, let alone anything else. That is one example I would cite as evidence of the value of the visit.

Secondly, we met a great number of people in the countries we visited. The message we received, particularly from people in less than official positions, was of a considerable amount of goodwill, intelligence and concern. Certainly there is considerable frustration on the part of many people in those countries, people of goodwill, who dearly wish to see a solution to the appalling tragedy that continues to prevail in the Middle East. The opportunity to meet our Australian colleagues in the embassies and missions was something we all benefited from. I second the remarks of Senator Colston along those lines.

The Israeli people and the Palestinian people whom we met highlighted that evidence of care and concern, of intelligence and goodwill, of dealing with the terrible frustration of more than 40 years of continuous, or near continuous, occupation and war in that area. None of those people celebrate that; in fact, they mourn considerably that ongoing tragedy. Again, that is something that one can read about. A quite shocking photograph of yet another disaster in the Middle East crossed our desks this morning. Even though that conveys the appalling situation, it does not convey anything like the impressions we all gained from actually visiting the territory.

I wanted to relate the learning experience I had from visiting the refugee camps. I was not able to join the delegation until Amman, so I missed the visit to Syria; but I visited the Palestinian camp in Amman and two camps in the Gaza Strip area, in the occupied territories. We were advised, when we visited the camp just outside of Amman, that it was really a very good camp; the standards and conditions there were very reasonable and admirable. Certainly, one could only say that, on a relative score, it was better than the camps in Gaza. But if ever we settle for the poverty in that camp in Amman as being acceptable, we will have reached as a very sorry state.

Conditions in that camp are appalling. People there are doing their very best in shocking conditions to try to live with some kind of dignity and decency. We were particularly interested in health issues. We visited the health centre and travelled with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) people, who are providing much of that assistance for the Palestinian people in those camps. Despite all of that good will and the considerable effort that is being made, one cannot overlook unsealed roads, sewage flowing in the streets-if not always sewage, at least effluent of some sort; open drains and so on. There are piles of rubbish, food refuse and animals and children growing up together. There are appalling limitations on the space to which any family has access. As I recollect it-I will not go to the wall on the accuracy of this recollection-families are allocated 100 square metres of ground on which they can build accommodation-or have it built for them with their assistance. We met one family in just such a place, comprising one wife and seven children, living in a room which was about 15 feet square. The children were able to play in an outside area which measured 30 feet by 15 feet. As those children grow and the families establish new and separate families, the remaining space is subdivided.

The health centre, which was very clean, was very sparse. It had concrete floors, concrete walls, a tin roof and very little in the way of grass, asphalt or anything to keep down dust and dirt. There was no such thing as a playground. When I asked-not from innocence-where the playgrounds were, it was made absolutely clear that there were none. I was later advised that there were some playground areas in the Gaza Strip camps and that these had been closed-if one can use that word. The military did not want the Palestinian people in the Gaza camps having the opportunity even to meet in the playground areas, such as they were.

The squalor and poverty in those camps cannot be ignored or overlooked. I believe that we must face up to the appalling situation in those camps. For many of those people it has been over 40 years since they moved to those camps. There is a third generation of people whose lives have been confined by the poverty and limitations of the circumstances there. Much of the work-much of the provision of care-is provided with the support of the UNHCR people, but it is provided by the Palestinian people themselves. There are people with great good will from other countries who have contributed to the effort of trying to provide basic necessities for the people in those camps. I believe it is time for the United Nations to take very serious stock of its commitment and responsibility in this area. No solution in the Palestinian camps can be reached until a political solution in the Middle East is reached. As the United Nations had a considerable hand in the establishment of the state of Israel, it seems to me that the United Nations has a considerable responsibility for the political solution in this area.

It is distressing to me that the United Nations, to some extent, and relief moneys from all sources, to a huge extent, contribute to the education, clothing, health care and basic necessities in those camps in Jordan, the West Bank, Gaza, Lebanon and Syria, for over 760,000 Palestinian refugees. That does not take account of the 1 1/2 million refugees not living in camps. Of those people living in camps, much of the care, education and training of all sorts is provided by contributions through aid dollars. In some ways the local governments, the local authorities, are abdicating or not assuming the responsibility for the care of those people. They are, if you like, a burden on the rest of the world. The rest of the world is very committed, to a considerable extent, to making sure that people in these areas do not die of starvation and neglect. I certainly do not want in any way to be seen to criticise UNHCR, whose efforts in this area have been absolutely fantastic, but they are working against the odds. They continue to represent, while there is no political solution in the Middle East, the improper direction for all of that effort. There must be some political will to find a political solution so that many of those other bandaid or other stopgap measures on behalf of people, to provide their basic human necessities, will no longer be necessary.

In case I am misunderstood, I do not want to blame any particular group more than another. The Palestinian refugees are victims and political pawns in an appalling game. They have been forgotten by the authorities in the countries in which they are camped. Certainly, we were advised that they are used by some Palestinian people to perpetuate their political ambitions. The misery and the appalling conditions in which those people are growing up confirmed to me what can be guessed at from looking at the descriptions from this distance; but to see the conditions myself confirmed how appalling, how shocking and how degrading they are. I say simply that I was amazed and humbled by the way in which people growing up and living in those camps do so with considerable dignity and a capacity to optimise their care and concern for each other under those shocking conditions.

One of my other interests that I was pleased to be able to touch on briefly while I was in the Middle East is APHEDA. These letters stand for the Australian People Health Education Development Abroad organisation, which is a non-government organisation which provides aid. It is now the official aid arm of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and it has projects in many countries around the world. While we were in Nablus in the occupied territories, we visited St Luke's Hospital, where I met people who could talk to me about some of the APHEDA nurse training in that area. The Gaza camp also had some APHEDA trained nurses and I was able to speak to the people there about the training program. There are other projects undertaken by APHEDA. I do not wish to stress those now, but I do cite those two cases with which we had contact while we were in the Middle East.

I support Senator Colston's remarks about the challenge to democracy that must occur when civil rights of certain sections of the community are not guaranteed or protected. That is certainly something that we saw. When we visited Gaza we were certainly-fortunately, we were only on the edge of such areas-discommoded by the tear gas that was thrown at the time not very far from us. We also saw stone throwing, not only by young people but also by some of the Israeli military people. We could see the evidence of ongoing disruption and terror that prevails for the people living there. We were, to some extent, unhappy to know that our visit might have been cited as causal of yet another piece of disruption but any reading of the news reports from that area would suggest that we would not have to feel too responsible, as that kind of disruption had been going on long before we came and it has continued, as I read the newspaper, to happen to this point. I also find it very distressing that in this whole recent Intifada uprising over 200 Palestinian people have died, and I believe four Israelis though those figures may in fact not be completely accurate or up to date. That loss of life will continue. It is an appalling continuing indictment added to the other points that I have had to make about what I think are wretched conditions there, and continuing evidence, from what our delegation saw, of why there is a real need for the political will to focus on finding or trying to find processes to begin the steps of solution in this area.

I do urge people to look at the report although it is only a summary of many pieces of information, descriptions of visits, and so on that came our way while we were there. Much of it is pretty provocative and disturbing information, some of it very encouraging. In the midst of considerable distress and difficulties there are rays of hope that I think occur when one meets quite splendid people. One of those people is a woman named Jean Calder, an Australian doctor of philosophy who did her training in physical education to start with and is now working with handicapped children. She, first of all, was working in Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon. She is now working in Cairo, Egypt, and enjoys considerable support and sympathy from the Australian ambassador there. That is how we were able to meet Jean and then go and visit her and some of the children in her care and the care of Egyptian and Palestinian people. The centre that provides the care for the children in Cairo is not restricted to providing assistance for Palestinian people. It is to help disabled people of whatever sort and, of course, many Egyptian people are able to benefit from her care.

While we were there we were also able to meet Fathi Arafat who was able to give us a considerably detailed description of the Palestinian Red Crescent organisation, so that while not part of the more official visits of the delegation it was a very interesting and fruitful time indeed. Again I find it heartening to meet people of such generosity. They do give some optimism in a fairly pessimistic and bleak scene. In case I should leave people with the impression that the only optimism there was one Australian woman in Cairo, I would hasten to correct that impression. I would simply confirm again that the many people we met-in particular I would say the Palestinian and Israeli people who are of good will, who are of concern, who do desire very much to see the end of war and the beginning of peace in this unhappy region-gave great cause for optimism and I am certainly most appreciative that I could be part of this delegation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think probably most of the things that need to be said regarding this parliamentary delegation to the Middle East to specifically look at the Israeli-Palestine conflict and the situation there have been said. There are several things that I would like to add. Firstly, I regard it as a great opportunity given to me by this Parliament to be a member of that delegation, even though the experiences, particularly as Senator Crowley has indicated, in Gaza and on the West Bank were particularly harrowing. I notice that Peter Roberts and Graham Bauer are sitting up in the gallery. I would like to pay tribute to their work in helping the delegation both by way of advice and help, while we were on the trip, and also in writing the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters I would like to stress relate to the emerging problem of population and environmental degradation in the Middle East, because it became quite clear to me that underlying and interwoven with the political problem in the Middle East is this very severe and exacerbating problem of the mismatch between population and the ability of the environment to support that population. It relates not only to Israel and the areas claimed by the Palestinian people but indeed it relates to Egypt, Jordan and Syria, and even to countries like Saudi Arabia. Indeed, as we flew over the deserts of Saudi Arabia and we looked down from a height of over 30,000 feet, we saw green patches laid out on this otherwise white desert. On inquiry it turned out that these green patches were areas of grain being grown with irrigated water. This water was being taken essentially from fossil beds of water underneath the desert and were rapidly being depleted. It is a type of agriculture which clearly cannot persist for very long into the future.

In Jordan we found that the city of Amman which is essentially a post-war city of nearly a million people was deriving a large part of its water supply from an oasis out in the eastern desert and this oasis was, again, steadily being depleted. One sees there a large and growing population dependent upon a water supply which has no assured future. Turning to Gaza, one found there a population of almost a million people, a doubling of that population in only 17 years, and yet living on an aquifer which was being rapidly depleted and into which salt was encroaching from the Mediterranean Sea. Even the little agriculture which was available to the Palestinian people in Gaza was under very severe threat.

Perhaps of immediate concern to Australia should be the observation that Egypt was exporting some 80 per cent of its food production only 20 years ago. It is now importing 80 per cent of its food needs and Egypt is one the greatest importers of Australian wheat. Of course that importation of Australian wheat can persist only as long as Egypt is maintained with international loans and should the international monetary funds decide one of these days, perhaps in the not too distant future, that it is no longer going to support Egypt, then Australia is going to be in dire straits with regard to its wheat exports.

The situation in the Middle East is indeed very depressing. It is depressing because of the apparently intractable problem which has arisen between the Palestinian people and the Israelis. Underlying this problem one has the situation that throughout the whole region those populations are growing very rapidly, with doubling times of the order of 20 years. Those populations have already exceeded the capacity of the land there to supply even their basic requirements such as food and water. Of course there is no possibility of a solution to that problem until and unless the political one is solved because in speaking particularly to Palestinians one of the principal reasons given for wanting to increase their population is to take back what they see as their land which has been occupied by Israel. When inquiring at the various medical centres that we visited as to what component of those medical programs was directed towards population control, contraception, fertility and so on, one found that an extremely small fraction of those medical programs were directed in that way. Such programs were anathema to the political interests of the Palestinian people.

In conclusion, I would simply point out that I think it is very important that Australia press very hard through the United Nations and whatever channels it has available to it for a political solution. Looking beyond that, even if there is a political solution, there will be a continuing and worsening problem to which Australia and all other countries in fortunate positions must direct their attention. That must involve not only better methods of agriculture but particularly direct efforts to control population growth because without that the situation in the Middle East will continually worsen. Also the population environment problem will reflect back on continuing political problems and those problems will indeed become completely intractable.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report is the first report on variations to the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs tabled by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The work on this report was done by the joint subcommittee on variations. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure is also tabling the same report today. This first report covers variation 1987-1, containing one proposal; variation 1988-2, containing eight proposals, and variation 1988-1, containing four proposals. SPEECH.PARA: The joint subcommittee approved the variations to the plan of layout but expressed its concern that the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) administration failed to refer variation 1987-1 to the joint subcommittee for proper parliamentary scrutiny before construction of the security fence at the United States Embassy commenced. In relation to current Committee arrangements, last October and November the Senate and the House of Representatives passed resolutions referring the matter of variations of the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs to their respective standing committees on transport, communications and infrastructure for inquiry and report. The resolutions also empowered the committees to sit as a joint subcommittee to consider the variations matter.

Not only is the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and its counterpart in the House of Representatives, charged with reviewing variations to the plan of Canberra but also the leasehold system in the ACT is the subject of inquiry by the committees. The situation which has arisen where these responsibilities are currently discharged by a joint subcommittee in unsatisfactory and cumbersome for a number of reasons. For instance, not all ACT members and senators are members of the standing committees and thus cannot participate fully in the activities of the joint subcommittee. Further, all ACT matters have to be referred specifically by each chamber to its standing committee and all subcommittee reports have to be referred back to each standing committee for subsequent approval. Such reliance on a clumsy structure of committees and subcommittees with their divisions of responsibility and authority to scrutinise ACT matters confuses the public and denies easy access to the Parliament. This convoluted process of inquiry is clearly unsatisfactory. There is an urgent need for a joint committee on the ACT. This committee would enable the Federal Parliament to carry out its ongoing role to oversee the planning and development of the national capital on behalf of the nation. Further, it would provide for efficient and expeditious inquiry into matters pertaining to the ACT and provide the public with an easy access to Parliament and the opportunity to provide an input at the Federal level into ACT matters which impact on the national development of Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: to inquire into and advise the Minister of any other matters relating to tertiary institutions which may be referred to it by the Minister or which the Commission itself considered to be matters of inquiry.

In a public statement issued on 1 October, 1987 the Commission expressed its unanimous support for three essential principles which should characterise any structure for Commonwealth involvement in higher education. In particular, it believed there should be a statutory authority with the right to prepare and publish independent reports, and with responsibility not only for recommending the allocation of resources, but also for implementing approved programs and expenditures (in accordance with Government decisions) and for monitoring outcomes. SPEECH.PARA: The second area that the report covered was the inconsistency in sentencing practice. I note that the Law Reform Commission makes a number of recommendations for improving consistency in sentencing, which I think we all recognise is a shortcoming in our criminal law system at present. It suggested, for example, that there be more extensive requirements for the giving of reasons for decisions and that a statutory list of factors regarded as relevant to the exercise of the court's discretion should exist. It made some interesting suggestions such as a discount being given on a sentence for a plea of guilty. I must say that I do not agree with that. Nevertheless, it is an interesting debating point. Most importantly, the Commission suggested:

. . . judicial officers need reliable, accessible and up to date information, not only to impose appropriate penalties on individual offenders but also to help ensure that sentences imposed are consistent.

It develops this proposal by suggesting more fully that an information system, which does not exist at the moment, should cover both the quantitative and qualitative components that are necessary in sentencing practice.

I commend those aspects of the report. The only other area that I want to touch upon at the moment is the reference in the report to corporate offenders. In the report the Commission mentions the problems that existed in relation to sentencing in the corporate world and suggested that a further specific reference should be given for inquiry and report into controlling corporate behaviour through the criminal justice system. This leads one to an earlier discussion paper on corporate offences that was put out by the Commission. It reminds us that death and physical injury often result from corporate crime. That is important because we do not really think of corporate crime in terms of harming the individual. It noted that, despite the substantial amount of harm caused by corporate crime, most regulatory bodies show a strong preference for reliance upon civil remedies and self-regulation rather than resort to criminal prosecution. When the Commission looked at the remedy of fines it noted, and it is most interesting, that the severity of fines in the corporate area generally has been extremely mild and has only minimal deterrent impact. This also is an important conclusion that requires further detailed consideration by this Senate. SPEECH.PARA: Every aspect of the waterfront industry-management, training, government responsibility, and the monopoly nature-has been criticised by the preliminary findings of the Inter-State Commission's Waterfront Investigation, released yesterday.

It is inefficient, overpriced, unreliable, cost ineffective and riddled with ineffective and inefficient work practices. It brings Australia's trade very much into an uncompetitive position, as stated in the report. Senator Panizza outlined nine of the major problems identified in the report and I do not intend to repeat them. However, I underline the great importance of getting the waterfront right because this country should develop an export culture and a far more expanded export trade to ensure its economic development and security. It is quite clear that Australia will remain a trading nation for many centuries to come, but the costs of our waterfront practices at the moment are substantially holding back our development when we compare ourselves with the competition to our immediate north in Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: What are some of the solutions that are outlined in the report. We must be positive and look to the future in this regard. The Commission's report outlines seven steps to try to clean up the mess on the waterfront. Firstly, it suggests that we should have more effective management in the stevedoring industry and a more well-motivated work force. I guess that supposes that there should be the introduction of all kinds of incentives and better work conditions in order to stimulate the management and the work force to work more closely together. Secondly, there should be a strengthening of the influence of both exporters and importers in obtaining some say as to how the waterfront should be managed. Thirdly, there should be an improvement in the accountability of the industry itself. There should be public records, there should be public presentation of the financial results, and there should be public accountability for the activities of both management and the work force. In that way public debate can be stimulated and improvements initiated in the full blaze of publicity.

Fourthly, we should drastically improve industrial relations and, of course, the accompanying dispute settlement procedures which until now, in their antiquated form, have bedevilled the waterfront. The time has come for drastic change in order to re-establish far better and closer relationships between workers and managers. Fifthly, there should be far more emphasis on the workings of the market in the provision of infrastructure and services. Quite clearly, too many of Australia's resources are tied up with the very heavy costs of establishing infrastructure and of maintaining services at the waterfront. Clearly, that needs to change. Clearly, we need to become more efficient in that area and produce new means of productivity to ensure that the infrastructure works more effectively. Sixthly, the Commission recommends the abolition of anti-competitive practices on the waterfront by both management and labour. That clearly is an area which opens itself to opportunities for change and constructive discussion between labour and management. Finally, the report recommends the establishment of a body to coordinate and manage the whole strategy that has been outlined in the report. Quite clearly, the report is valuable. It has been a long time in coming. It now remains to be seen whether the Government will pick up the ball and run with it. Clearly, the opportunity is there for it to do that. We are aware that there is to be a change of Minister in this area. Perhaps when that has occurred we will see some action from the Government, which has been dragging its tail in this area since it came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the repeated refusal of Government Ministers in this Chamber to give any guarantee that the Prime Minister would not call an early election in 1988 for both Houses of Parliament if he were given the power to do so by a `yes' vote in the Referendum on Saturday, 3 September 1988;

I do not remember a set of referendum proposals that have been so deceptive and dishonest. I do not remember referendum proposals that have deliberately received so little attention, publicity or support from the Government which, on this occasion, has set out to make certain that the people of Australia do not know what the issues really are. Not one of the proposals actually does what it purports to do, and most of them do exactly the opposite. Instead of protecting Australia and Australians, they expose them to risks. Instead of extending the likely term of the Parliament, they effectively create a situation in which such terms can be significantly reduced.

The first question is the one that concerns me most and is the subject of my motion. It suggests, quite improperly, that, if carried, it will extend the term of the Parliament and reduce the number of elections. In fact, the deceptive booklet which contains the Yes case, which has been printed at public expense and distributed to some, but not all, Australians in a proper way-I will deal with that point later-states:
By voting YES for four-year maximum terms for Federal Parliament you can help stop this practice.

The public will be spared the disruption caused by having too many elections.
That is simply, uncomplicatedly false. The booklet continues:

It is true that the business community supports four-year terms, but it is totally false that it supports this crooked proposal that this crooked Government has put up in this crooked way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is making these false statements?

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is, of course, that this Government is using the proposition, which it has used invariably that any change is for the better. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes to raise one issue about this new building. I refer to a sign which I noticed today for the first time in the public area on the first floor, a sign that said `Mothers Room'. I do not know who is responsible, the Joint House Department or the Parliament House Construction Authority, but whoever is responsible should take note that such a reference to a room is anachronistic, sexist and certainly insensitive. It continues to entrench attitudes which ought to be out of date-that mothers are the only people responsible for the caring of babies and that fathers are not able or expected to perform tasks such as changing nappies or feeding. Certainly if the mother is breast feeding, the father is less able to help. But even in that case it is sometimes appropriate for both partners to assist in that process.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly believe it is wrong for us to have a room that is labelled as a mothers room. Even a few years ago at the Trans Australia Airlines concourse at Melbourne Airport, what was a similar room had the sign changed to one which was non-specific about the care of children. I think it is very good that there is such a room here and that it was included in the brief and built. But the question is: what should it be called? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Parliament the inconsistencies of a report which appeared in yesterday's Canberra Times. It is not my normal approach to criticise the printed media; however, in this instance, I feel that I am obliged to set the record straight. The large article, which was on the front page, was titled `Tasmanian parasite puts meat exports in jeopardy'. The very nature of this heading is enough, I believe, to cause concern. The article does no justice to the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry, nor does it do justice to the Tasmanian meat industry, which has an enviable record for both its quality and controls.

SPEECH.PARA: Mention is also made in the article of the testing facilities available through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Whilst I do not agree totally with some of the comments made, I am at this stage more concerned in setting the record straight with regard to Tasmania. Unfortunately, as is so often the case, the Canberra Times has chosen not to print in today's edition a follow-up on the story, and so there may be some who have gained the wrong impression.

The article concerns the death of three tiger quolls-native cats-which it is believed may have died from Trichinella spiralis, which is an exotic parasite capable of having very detrimental effects on humans and wildlife. The article claims that Trichinella spiralis spreads between animals when they consume meat containing the infected cysts. Quite rightly, it points out that Australia has prided itself upon its exporting of only clean pork, an industry which is worth some $14m to the Australian economy.

The implications from the article are that the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry may have been remiss in the handling of this matter and that these actions could have placed the industry in jeopardy. However, quite assuredly this is not the case and my investigations have convinced me that not only has the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry handled this matter in a most effective manner, but it has also quite rightly attempted to downplay the hysterical reactions which could quite easily have developed from such an issue. We have only to hark back to the pubic hysteria that occurred over the kangaroo meat fiasco, and the damage that caused our meat industry, to realise what could happen.

Today I am pleased to announce in this chamber that the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nick Evers, has advised that testing for the trichinella in 1,768 pig samples from Tasmanian abattoirs has given a 100 per cent parasite free result. Mr Evers has also confirmed that the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry ensured that prompt advice of the incident was relayed to veterinarians and public health authorities throughout the State following earlier advice to all Commonwealth and State officials through the consultative committee on existing animal diseases.

The upshot of all this is that the tests have proven conclusively that Tasmania's pork industry has not been affected by the discovery of the parasite in some native wildlife species. While a positive identification of the parasite is yet to be made, it could safely be advised that it is likely that this Australian variant of trichinella, having a strict marsupial dependent life cycle, will have little or no effect on Tasmania's meat and livestock exports. This could be further supported by the fact that some rats, mice and cats from the area have been examined and found to be unaffected by the parasite.

It is believed that the infection may have been present in Tasmania for some time. However, it is being regarded as an infection confined to undomesticated species and will present little, if any, danger to human health. Both Mr Evers and the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry are unhappy with the delay in testing the nature of the parasite by the laboratory in Atlanta; however, it is a matter which has been largely out of their control.

It is also important that the Parliament notes that the pork industry within Tasmania operates under the most stringent guidelines and that the feeding of swill to pigs in Tasmania has been controlled for many years and no piggeries are licensed to feed kitchen waste to pigs. In concluding, I would also like to raise the possibility that this matter could have affected Tasmania's game industry. I do not know whether any honourable senators present have had the opportunity to taste Tasmanian game; if they have not, I would strongly suggest that they do because it is very enjoyable. But the point I make is that Tasmanian game species, not being carnivores, are unlikely to be implicated in any way. Animals are most likely to be affected by eating other animals or carrion in which there are muscle larvae.

Mr President, I hope that I have set the record straight on this matter, that you enjoy your meal, and that I may have done some good in ensuring that the full story is understood. I would not like anyone to think that Tasmania had been lax in this matter or that Tasmania would put the meat export industry at risk. This is not the case and simply has not happened.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
